top_comment.text:
We watched this video in my Principles of Wildlife Management class. It's a 
really good video, to be sure, and top-down cascades are really important, 
but keep in mind that no environment is a perfect balance - there is a 
constant struggle between all species to increase their population as much 
as possible and wolves are no exception. This has the potential to become a 
problem because between the wolves in the park and the hunters outside of 
the park, the elk population in and around Yellowstone has been reduced to 
about only 8,000. Before you jump on hunters for wanting to hunt the elk 
too, keep in mind that a lot of these conservation programs are funded BY 
hunters and fishermen. We wouldn't have the money for these programs 
without the hunters through hunting leases and permits, as well as taxes on 
hunting equipment.﻿

top_comment.text:
*Complex interrelationships between Earth and life.* Changing levels of a 
single species can have far-reaching impacts on local plants and animals - 
and even change the course of rivers. 

*"When we try to pick out anything by itself, we find it hitched to 
everything else in the Universe."* John Muir

We have discovered that food chains are also webs - and that complex 
interrelationships can have far-reaching impacts that are difficult to 
predict.

The human-led near-extermination of the wolves changed Yellowstone. The 
human-led attempt to undo the damage changed it, too.  But additional 
studies show that not all that was lost has been restored:

● Stream hydrology limits recovery of riparian ecosystems after wolf 
reintroduction. (
http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/280/1756/20122977)

● Are wolves saving Yellowstone's aspen? A landscape-level test of a 
behaviorally mediated trophic cascade. (
http://www.wyocoopunit.org/index.php/archives/2010/kauffman-m-j-j-brodie-and-e-s-jules-2010-are-wolves-saving-yello/
)

We know that the activities of humans and other species can create 
fascinating and long-term changes in our environment. Predicting those 
changes - and how those changes may affect us - remains a difficult and 
important challenge.

+Stanford University scientists published a study on the loss of animals in 
the Anthropocene, the Earth's current geologic time period,  where the rise 
of humans and human activities have begun a significant impact on the 
Earth's ecosystems. 

*[H]uman impacts on animal biodiversity are an under-recognized form of 
global environmental change. Among terrestrial vertebrates, 322 species 
have become extinct since 1500, and populations of the remaining species 
show 25% average decline in abundance. Invertebrate patterns are equally 
dire: 67% of monitored populations show 45% mean abundance decline. Such 
animal declines will cascade onto ecosystem functioning and human 
well-being.*

http://www.sciencemag.org/content/345/6195/401

http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/07/140724171956.htm

"Two billion years ago, cyanobacteria oxygenated the atmosphere and 
powerfully disrupted life on earth,” [Andrew Revkin] says. “But they didn’t 
know it. We’re the first species that’s become a planet-scale influence and 
is aware of that reality. That’s what distinguishes us.”

http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/what-is-the-anthropocene-and-are-we-in-it-164801414/#u4Rc8ff87u3KmGAL.99

  #interconnected   #ecology   #earthscience   #lifescience﻿

top_comment.text:
*Returning Wolves Brought New Life to Yellowstone Park*

It is far from intuitively obvious that introducing a predator would result 
in the other species thriving, but that's what happened when Wolves were 
returned to Yellowstone Park after having been eradicated completely for 70 
years. The wolves brought the animal population back into balance, allowing 
not plants and other animals to thrive. The thriving plant life even 
changed the flow of the rivers. This is proof once again that *every* part 
of an ecosystem plays an important role in maintaining the ecosystem's 
health. ﻿
top_comment.author: John Skeats

comments.text: +Cynthia Anderson Thanks. That's very powerful in itself.
comments.author: John Skeats

comments.text:
+John Skeats I am short on time at the moment, so cannot search articles. 
However, this is a quote taken from www.nps.gov "The effect of wolf 
recovery on the dynamics of northern Yellowstone elk cannot be generalized 
to other elk populations in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem. The effects 
depend on a complex of factors including elk densities, abundance of other 
predators, presence of alternative ungulate prey, winter severity, 
and—outside the park—land ownership, human harvest, livestock depredations, 
and humancaused wolf deaths. A coalition of natural resource professionals 
and scientists representing federal and state agencies, conservation 
organizations and foundations, academia, and land owners are collaborating 
on a comparative research program involving three additional wolf-ungulate 
systems in the western portion of the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem. 
Results to date indicate the effects of wolf predation on elk population 
dynamics range from substantial to quite modest."   I can tell you that I 
live and spend a great deal of time outdoors in both Idaho and Washington 
where wolves have repopulated.  Since wolf reintroduction, I have seen a 
rapid decline in the number of animals seen (mostly in Idaho, but now 
starting in Washington), as well as sign of their presence, but have 
certainly seen an increase in wolf sign and sightings.  I have also spent a 
great deal of time in Yellowstone, both during the time of large elk herds 
and since wolf reintroduction.  I don't need an article to tell me that the 
herds of elk had high numbers because they were not hunted (that is common 
sense). I also didn't need an article to tell me that high numbers of 
ungulates, whether deer, elk, bison, antelope, moose, or whatever are going 
to eat down the vegetation.  In the areas outside of national parks, I have 
never seen areas that have been so overpopulated by ungulates that they 
overgrazed or overbrowsed the vegetation.  That is in large part because 
hunting helped keep populations under control.  It shouldn't take a 
scientist to prove that wildlife numbers in Yellowstone were high because 
of no hunting within the park and relatively more balanced outside of the 
park because management of wildlife involves hunting.  I am not saying that 
wolves don't have their place in the ecosystem outside of the park, but to 
believe the wildlife conditions that lie within the park boundaries are the 
same as those outside of the boundaries is foolhardy
comments.author: Cynthia Anderson

comments.text: +Cynthia Anderson Can you point me to any articles about that?
comments.author: John Skeats

comments.text:
+John Skeats The problem with this is that Yellowstone Park is not 
representative of the majority of the natural ecosystem. Yellowstone's elk 
population was unnaturally high because there was no hunting within the 
park. So while introducing wolves to the park did reduce the numbers, thus 
creating the situation discussed in this video, this is not representative 
of the majority of the rest of the habitat into which wolves have been 
reintroduced.  Many people take this story and apply it to the rest of 
nature but it doesn't work that way in the rest of the world.
comments.author: Cynthia Anderson

comments.author: r4ptur3B

comments.text:
+Bweiss1234 You’re relying too much on biting, sarcastic rhetoric in your 
post rather than actual information.  Bear in mind, I’m not trying to 
condescend you, I simply want to hear where you’re getting your info from.

Now, erosion is always happening in rivers, that is true, but the rate of 
erosion that occurs in these rivers is far slower than you’re claiming. 
However, it’s been clearly established that the presence of wolves has 
reduced the artificially high levels of elk who graze along the Yellowstone 
river, resulting in the growth of more willows along this river. Since 
willows thrive in a river environment, this creates an increased amount of 
willow range in the river, and as more trees spring up (and there are more 
species than willows that have been affected, mind you, the willows are 
simply the most prominent example,) the more sediment is trapped.  Since 
the flow rate of the river has not increased, it stands to reason that the 
river would naturally change course.

Now, as for your point on hunting the wolves, yes, I believe that to a 
certain extent, wolves should still be hunted (to a sustainable extent) if 
they repeatedly venture onto ranch lands and pose a threat to the cattle, 
or if their population reaches such a level that the elk populations drop 
below sustainable levels.  But saying that the small negative effect on 
humans by the reintroduction of wolves is justification to paint all wolves 
with the same negative brush is like saying that all guns should be banned 
because a few mass murders occur with them.  It’s not only unfair, it’s 
also illogical.
comments.author: r4ptur3B

top_comment.text:
And now I want to share with you one of the most interesting short videos 
I've seen in a while. It's about the idea of *trophic cascades:* how a 
small change to an ecosystem can lead to tremendous consequences. In this 
case, the change was the reintroduction of wolves to Yellowstone in the 
1990's, after a 70-year absence.

The direct effects of the wolves were small: the wolves eat a few deer, but 
apart from that mostly keep to themselves. But the indirect effects were 
huge.

It started because the deer, who had been running roughshod over the entire 
park, quickly figured out that places like valleys were *not good places* 
to be a deer when there are wolves about. This led to trees being able to 
grow in those areas for the first time in decades.

The effects of that are complex and profound, and I encourage you to watch 
the video, because I can't possibly summarize it better than it does. 
Everything from the animals to the plants to the very physical geography of 
the rivers was changed. 

The key lesson of this is that ecosystems are connected. You can't make a 
single change to one and expect it not to have consequences, including very 
far-reaching ones of a sort you couldn't ever have predicted. This is a 
general property of all large, strongly-interacting systems, including 
societies, and it's worth keeping in mind whenever things change.﻿

comments.text:
Comrade Alex:  The first quote is from scott S.  The second is in response 
to the Disnyesque way some portray wolves, and the arrogant way people who 
have probably never been in wolf country foolishly speak of  them as good 
neighbors when history - that I've provided ample links to - proves 
otherwise.  I never SAID wolves are unnecessary, but we got along just fine 
without them for 70 years in my neck of the woods before we were 
re-infested, so history suggests it's true.

If you had 'endangered' wolves roaming your area your legal right to 'drive 
them back from the perimeter lines'  is prohibited by the ESA, lawyers, 
judges, Defenders of Wildlife, Sierra Club, Nature Conservancy and others 
or risk jail and fines.  The ESA specifically ignores financial loss and 
personal safety when dealing with 'listed' species.

Finally, if you think you can just go for a stroll in the woods and kill 
wolves, you are mistook because they are elusive.  Wolves find you.  Three 
to six in a pack, from three to six directions at once.  Good luck with 
that shotgun. Watch the videos I posted of wolves vs Moose and wolves vs 
bison.  Their tactics put a whole new meaning to the word 'wolfgang'  and 
exhaust the victim.

Just to be clear:  The majority of 'killing sprees' are done by federal 
fish and game wolf managers, the same ones who re-infested the rocky 
mountains with wolves.   These wolfers "hunt" from helicopters - something 
taxpayers are prohibited from doing - home in on homing signals from the 
wolf's radio tracking collar - and wipe out packs that are habituated to 
beef, mutton, dog or daughter.  Carter Neimeier was such a person, and he's 
pro-wolf.  Glance thru his book here 
http://www.amazon.com/Wolfer-A-Memoir-Carter-Niemeyer/dp/0984811303/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1397779204&sr=8-1&keywords=wolfer

Neimeyer says that the best thing to happen to wolves is a wolf hunting 
season:  It makes them wary.  Wolf attacks occur when seemingly innocent 
encounters - sharing a snack with a wolf - turns deadly for the sharer or 
girlfriend snoozing nearby.  See references posted earlier.

comments.text:
+Pro Angler Dude, there is no over-population of wolves.  As a disclaimer, 
I am a little offensive, but I do make good points/opinions and not all of 
them are against your opinions; I truly do just have an abrasive 
personality when it comes to all things natural, wild, and (should be!) 
free. 
There is no over-population of wolves anywhere in the U.S. - no matter what 
people who sell you their expensive tags say.  People will shoot wolves 
legally and illegally, so I think that to maintain (I say again, MAINTAIN) 
natural populations of other animals we need to keep all the wolves we can. 
 People will always shoot wolves for reasons either legitimate or 
illegitimate reasons (natural wolf populations will always be low due to 
this human interference - let me emphasize the "interfere" part of that 
word).  One thing that cracks me up about this is this guy's separation of 
the "physical aspect of the landscape" and "ecosystem."  These wolves are a 
keystone species.  And let me define "keystone" for those who might 
overlook that word.  Keystone is a central most important aspect of a thing 
(in an arch, the keystone keeps it together - otherwise it would fall apart 
or weather and fall apart), and the wolves keep this ecosystem together. 
 This is where you would get over population (of deer) without it.  Maybe 
if hunters would hunt more deer, *we* would not "need" wolves to maintain 
the balance.  In fact, we would, but that's only if you care about your 
home, err, I mean the planet (one in the same, eh?).  The "other" side of 
this story is one that I should say that I am biased against, but not only 
because I think it is just completely silly to think that we "need" to 
eradicate a species because we do not like them coming onto "our" property 
and killing our livestock.  You know what?  That is a load of selfish BS. 
 If you think you need to kill a wolf for that reason that would be the 
ONLY thing that I would say could be considered warrant for the act of 
murdering such an important part of the natural world.  I say this solely 
because there is no way that anyone who would could be convinced not to 
kill a majestic animal such as Canis lupis.  Would you shoot your 
neighbor's dog?  Well, Mother Nature is not only your neighbor, but she 
also hosts your favorite hunting spots - you hunt on HER property.  I would 
have less of a problem if hunters hunted less for sport and prestige, and 
more for 1) survival, 2) respect, OR 3) protection (as in 
the aforementioned situation of a farmer protecting her/his livestock). 
 You hunt for food, or you hunt for the love of nature (for example, to 
lower deer populations when natural predators have been killed off and 
can't control the populations naturally).  I say, "love of nature," meaning 
the utmost respect, and I mean to maintain natural balance.  So you can 
tell with the wolves being gone for so long and the ecosystem going down 
the toilet, the hunters who did hunt in the area were not hunting for the 
love of nature, maybe for sport or food, but they did not hunt to maintain 
natural order.  So your argument is that to kill an apex predator is not 
for anything more than to "maintain natural order," it was not for the 
prestige of killing a magnificent relic of the ancient past (where did your 
fido come from?) it was not for the feelings of power of bringing down a 
deadly, big-bad wolf?  I say, if you want to hunt wolves for "fun," kill it 
with weapons that will make it more fair.  How did our ancestors kill 
wolves?  They either didn't or used bows or spears, harpoons or other 
throwing blades.  I'm sure other things, but they did not use the modern 
inventions of bullets and powder.  While it might be more "humane" (is it 
ever humane to kill a healthy wild animal?) to use a one-shot kill, it 
would be better to use more primitive tool.  This way,if you did miss, the 
wolf would have a chance to survive, or you would have to WORK for your 
prize.  Look at things from more than just a "I have to take a life to get 
off" perspective, and try to look at it like "I need to preserve as much of 
our natural world [for my kids and my neighbor's kids] as I can."  You do 
not need to be allowed to kill wolves to maintain their populations.  Once 
the deer population reaches it's new carrying capacity (the one that the 
abiotic and now new biotic - the wolves - factors have set) the wolf 
population will go to a stable one.  That is the natural order of things. 
 That IS the natural order of things.  In undisturbed ecosystems (hard to 
find these days), there is a natural cycle of a spike in prey species' 
populations (pop. for short) and then a spike in the predator's pop., and 
then you will see a plummet in the prey's pop. then a plummet in the 
predator's pop., then a spike in the prey's pop. not unlike that of the 
first  This is the natural cycle of things.  You do not need to kill 
"scary" things because they are scary.  You should kill them only when they 
attack or otherwise harm you (or your "property," including your wife or 
kids).
comments.author: Isis4211

movement in general, is just too great. We've destroyed this planet not

storage from those regenerating forests and the ecosystem services to 
survive. The top level predators WERE here first, and we have decimated so 
many ecosystems by removing them to meet our own ends. Even if you have an 
anthropocentric view on the matter, the ultimate benefits far outweigh the 
loss of a handful of cattle.

comments.text:
I thought this was utterly amazing when I saw it.. recently I was thinking 
it would be neat to write things like this into the ecologies of various 
monsters. For example, imagine a pack of lion-sized wyverns.

In open grasslands, there's no way to evade them, and so grazers must cling 
to the edges of forests so they can run for cover. As a result, whatever 
saplings do manage to sprout further away no longer get stripped of their 
soft bark and shoots, they manage to grow and develop into copses.

So, eventually, you wind up with a patchwork forest; large, dense copses 
separated by lanes of grasses. The grazers strip the copses of everything 
young, though, so you get these relatively clear, mature forests that die 
off after a hundred years, eventually turning into a mass of bare, standing 
trunks. Perfect for wyvern roosts.. and so eventually they repopulate with 
foliage.

top_comment.text:
Когда в 1995 году четырнадцать волков были выпущены на волю в 
Йеллоустонском национальном парке, ученые и не подозревали, что это 
кардинально изменит всю экосистему парка.

Волков не было в парке 70 лет и все это время там царствовали олени, 
которые за годы бесконтрольного размножения (все усилия людей по контролю 
их популяции не приносили успеха) нанесли сильнейший урон местной флоре. 
Четырнадцать волков, конечно, не смогли съесть всех оленей, но они 
заставили тех осторожнее выбирать места для пастбищ и избегать некоторых 
участков парка. На тех местах начала возрождаться растительность. За шесть 
лет количество деревьев увеличилось в пять раз. Появились бобры, которым 
деревья нужны для постройки плотин. В заводях завелись ондатры, утки и 
рыбы. Волки уменьшили популяцию шакалов, что привело к увеличению 
количества зайцев и мышей, а те в свою сторону привлекли в парк ястребов, 
хорьков и лис. В парк пришли медведи, так как они смогли отгонять волков от 
их добычи или доедать их объедки. В парке увеличилось количество ягод.

Но самое удивительное, волки изменили течение рек. Их русла выпрямились и 
стабилизировались, уменьшилась эрозия берегов. Случилось это потому, что 
влияние волков на оленей привело к взрывному росту деревьев и травы по 
берегам рек, что привело к их укреплению. Поменялась сама география парка, 
а все благодаря четырнадцати волкам, выпущенным туда менее двадцати лет 
назад.

http://mi3ch.livejournal.com/2709714.html﻿

top_comment.text:
And now I want to share with you one of the most interesting short videos 
I've seen in a while. It's about the idea of *trophic cascades:* how a 
small change to an ecosystem can lead to tremendous consequences. In this 
case, the change was the reintroduction of wolves to Yellowstone in the 
1990's, after a 70-year absence.

The direct effects of the wolves were small: the wolves eat a few deer, but 
apart from that mostly keep to themselves. But the indirect effects were 
huge.

It started because the deer, who had been running roughshod over the entire 
park, quickly figured out that places like valleys were *not good places* 
to be a deer when there are wolves about. This led to trees being able to 
grow in those areas for the first time in decades.

The effects of that are complex and profound, and I encourage you to watch 
the video, because I can't possibly summarize it better than it does. 
Everything from the animals to the plants to the very physical geography of 
the rivers was changed. 

The key lesson of this is that ecosystems are connected. You can't make a 
single change to one and expect it not to have consequences, including very 
far-reaching ones of a sort you couldn't ever have predicted. This is a 
general property of all large, strongly-interacting systems, including 
societies, and it's worth keeping in mind whenever things change.﻿

top_comment.text:
This is beautiful and fascinating.  Yonatan gives quite an adequate summary below, but I agree with him you really should just spend the 4 minutes and watch this. 

I began to think hard about ecosystems and their reliance on the death and suffering of some of its parts, and couldn't help but remark on how this complicates my sympathies for +David Pearce's philosophy of absolution of suffering.

I have some open questions, and would love input from anyone, but David if you're reading this like I think you are, I'd love a direct response.

First, how do we support ecosystems properly without carnivores?  Is there such a thing as "properly"?  
This ties into my second question:

Does anyone agree on what level of consciousness is required for an creature to deserve moral consideration?  By what metric are we quantifying this consciousness?

With a Google search, I found +David Pearce offering this: "Sentience is what makes another living being worthy of moral consideration, not IQ. And some non-human animals e.g. the sperm whale, with its 9 kg brain, may be more sentient than humans. One speciesist counter-argument says that humans matter more than equivalently sentient humans because human infants are “potentially” more intelligent than non-humans. http://arzone.ning.com/profiles/blogs/transcript-of-david-pearces#sthash.veM1zpFC.dpuf"

Is this a good metric?

I haven't found any good answers to these questions.
top_comment.author: Matthew J Price

comments.text:
+Matthew J Price Indeed this is something we talk about in vegan circles 
quite a bit, the way that every choice still leads to the destruction of 
habitat, insect species, etc. A life free of causing damage to others is 
not possible, and thus I consider veganism an effort to minimize impact 
(process rather than goal oriented). Even us in the western world live the 
way we do because of the exploitation of other human animals. It's arguable 
that survival requires exploitation, but that only works in an evolutionary 
context where only the fittest survive. We don't talk about wolves' 
exploitation of deer because due to that context of survival rather than 
morality.

Morality and ethics have little meaning in such a context. Should we think 
of ourselves as creatures who will do anything it takes to survive no 
matter how destructive and exploitative we become? Or should we think of 
ourselves as being part of a larger system where our survival is encouraged 
by diversity of other species, especially other competitive species?

*If we had a few wishes from the technology fairy to make this dilemma 
easier, or better, obviated, what would that look like?*

Wow, that is a question! I don't think of technology as other, but rather a 
reflection of the dominant (and often implicit) cultural values of those 
who create and use it. Thus, asking the technology fairy is really asking 
the cultural fairy. Consequently, I'll interpret your question as: How 
should us humans be different in order to make this dilemma easier? I think 
the root of a lot of our problems (in terms of exploitation and 
sustainability) is our ability to internalize what which we have and 
consider it 'normal'. Once we consider what we have as normal, getting used 
to less becomes a punishment. We always want more (growth) because we 
always adapt to that which we have. This is just greedy search.

I think technology (and capitalism) compound(s) this by driving 
'innovation' (read, change). I personally combat this tendency by 
intentionally keeping myself grounded in my technologies. I use the oldest 
(slowest) computer in my house the most because that way the oldest stays 
normal and thus the newer machines always feel fast (and thus new) it's 
like getting a new machine everytime I choose to do a job that needs speed.

In the broader sense, I get rid of X and see how it effects my life. This 
is how I came to veganism, one step at a time over many years. This 
involves an ongoing refinement of what 'need' means. I think the answer may 
be in cognition, maybe its as simple as being sceptical of what we have and 
thus expecting it not to be normal, imagining at any point it may 
disappear. I think this is also related to empathy. If we get used to 
dealing with people with the same values all the time, then the lack of 
conflict becomes normal, we become to expect others to be like us, and 
perhaps this makes it easier to cast others in the role of 'other'. As a 
species we hardly see other humans as equals, let alone alien intelligences 
like non-human animals with whom we can hardly communicate. We see 'others' 
as resources to support our own values in our communities. It's all very 
self-centred, as life is.

Actually, if we consider my previous comments on social animals, I'm 
starting to wonder if social ability is really the next frontier. We are 
not good survivors because we are intelligent, we are good survivors 
because we are social, and that requires intelligence. Maybe what we are 
testing (in the evolutionary sense) is the viability of a super-social 
creature. Either we expand like a virus, where our social abilities never 
catch up to our population, or we figure out how to get along and solve our 
problems together.

It seems clear that our selfish tendencies and social abilities are tuned 
to a community size significantly smaller than what we have. Either we 
change how we are social (get along in larger groups, empathize with and 
respect other species, build multi-species social systems to collaborate, 
rather than exploit), or we shrink our communities so that there is a 
better fit between our social tendencies, and our long-term survival.

The former is really the only viable option as the latter is gets to the 
ethical quandary of breeding control. It is clear the fastest growing 
populations are the least wealthy and least educated, and thus any such 
effort would be class warfare.

comments.author: Matthew J Price

comments.text:
+Matthew J Price:

*I began to think hard about ecosystems and their reliance on the death and 
suffering of some of its parts, and couldn't help but remark on how this 
complicates my sympathies for +David Pearce's philosophy of absolution of 
suffering.*

I don't think there is a necessary relationship between death and 
suffering. Both are ethical issues, but its certainly possible that death 
can involve no suffering and that suffering may not lead to death. In the 
context of this video, I find the death part much less interesting than the 
wolves' effect on the *behaviour* of other species. As in, the *threat* of 
death may be functional --- how we could maintain the illusion of threat 
without death is an open question. There is an interesting question 
regarding what is left for motivation when pain and suffering are removed. 
There are certainly interesting implications for evolution.

*First, how do we support ecosystems properly without carnivores?  Is there 
such a thing as "properly"?*

I do not consider evolution as a process of increasing X (intelligence, 
complexity, etc.); I think evolution a search process for finding useful 
local minima (ecological niches). After thousands of years of interactions 
(without humans), species reinforce their niches. Once you remove something 
from that system (wolves) then this significantly effects the rest of the 
system. Which is better? In this case it seems the wolves increased 
diversity by keeping the deer in check which I expect exploded in 
population during the wolves' absence. At the same time, this time without 
wolves was great for the deer, they probably had greater diversity (due to 
a reduction of predatory pressure), and certainly higher population. You 
give them an inch, they take a mile. To survive, any species will take all 
it can, and sustainable populations require constraints.

As for "properly", that is, of course, context dependent and value laden. I 
think the articulation of these terms is the most important thing we can do 
before we try and solve the (environmental) problems we have. Of course, 
what is good for us is bad for others. Unlike any other species, humans are 
really amazing at decreasing biodiversity. If we decide that biodiversity 
is important (more important than cheap energy and high 'quality of life'), 
then we need to figure out how to constrain ourselves, which is quite 
difficult considering survival is a central driver of life. Like deer, 
viruses or bacteria, we'll fill in all the niches we can because that is in 
our nature. What the ecosystem may need to work properly may just be less 
humans, a lot less. Who is to survive and why? Maybe intelligence, 
longevity and technology are actually those things that destine us for 
extinction; just as any population explodes, there is an inevitable 
correction. We do not live in isolation but depend on the ecosystem around 
us, as much as we build environments around us that distract us from this 
fact.

*Does anyone agree on what level of consciousness is required for an 
creature to deserve moral consideration?  By what metric are we quantifying 
this consciousness?*

There is a lot to unpack here. First I want to make a distinction between 
consciousness (sentience, awareness) and self-consciousness 
(awareness/construction of self). I think consciousness is ubiquitous among 
animals with brains, self-consciousness is a little more tricky. The 
question is always what evolutionary purpose does self-consciousness have? 
It seems to only be valuable for social animals.

As for moral consideration, it seems the central basis should be based on 
the ability to suffer, which I would put under the category of 
consciousness. An individual suffers if they are able to experience pain, 
and experiencing pain is expected to be a central aspect of awareness 
(consciousness).

As for metrics, we can imagine drawing a line between conscious animals and 
self-aware (social) animals. While those 'lower' animals suffer, we can get 
around that by not causing them suffering ('humane' treatment). We could 
feel justified in killing them because their lack of self-awareness means 
they cannot reflect on their impending end. I think this is a 
rationalization. By existing, all animals have gone through a long 
evolutionary process to become autonomous survivors. Interfering with their 
autonomy is us exercising our power over them (exploitation). For me, the 
question is not about metrics of consciousness, or drawing a line between 
'us' and 'them', but really about how we can engage in social relations 
with other animals that involve consent. This may only be possible with 
other social animals, but perhaps there are degrees of how social an animal 
is. Here is a twist, because we would be more likely to get consent from 
social animals (and engaging in mutually beneficial relationships), perhaps 
its even less ethical to exploit non-social (non-self-aware) animals. Thus, 
exploiting smart and self-aware social animals (whales, dolphins, rats, 
dogs, cats, birds, etc.) could be ethical in a context of consent, where 
the exploitation of non-self-aware animals (fish?) is never ethical. After 
writing this I'm not sure an actual non-social animal is a real thing, as 
tigers, pandas, etc. are considered solitary, and yet the fact that they 
can be domesticated seems to indicate they can be socialized.

Morality is equally context dependent and obviously value laden. Our 
current ethics reflect our belief that our (human) expansion trumps all 
else. Morality is about how humans are treated, and under what 
human-centric endeavour other animals can be exploited. The question of 
ethics exists *only* in a context of exploitation: We want to learn how to 
do X, so we can save lives, make money, etc.; under what circumstances can 
we exploit animals to do X? When we talk about ethics, we talk about *how* 
we can exploit others. The question of *whether* we should exploit at all 
is out of the question; by our nature, we are exploitative and 
self-centred. Such is life.

So what do we do with the awareness that we are destroying ourselves by 
destroying the ecosystem? Get as much as we can before the end, living as 
large as possible before the wolves come back? Or do we change our nature 
and restrain the tendency of life to take all that we can?
comments.author: Ben Bogart

top_comment.text:
Когда в 1995 году четырнадцать волков были выпущены на волю в 
Йеллоустонском национальном парке, ученые и не подозревали, что это 
кардинально изменит всю экосистему парка.

Волков не было в парке 70 лет и все это время там царствовали олени, 
которые за годы бесконтрольного размножения (все усилия людей по контролю 
их популяции не приносили успеха) нанесли сильнейший урон местной флоре. 
Четырнадцать волков, конечно, не смогли съесть всех оленей, но они 
заставили тех осторожнее выбирать места для пастбищ и избегать некоторых 
участков парка. На тех местах начала возрождаться растительность. За шесть 
лет количество деревьев увеличилось в пять раз. Появились бобры, которым 
деревья нужны для постройки плотин. В заводях завелись ондатры, утки и 
рыбы. Волки уменьшили популяцию шакалов, что привело к увеличению 
количества зайцев и мышей, а те в свою сторону привлекли в парк ястребов, 
хорьков и лис. В парк пришли медведи, так как они смогли отгонять волков от 
их добычи или доедать их объедки. В парке увеличилось количество ягод.

Но самое удивительное, волки изменили течение рек. Их русла выпрямились и 
стабилизировались, уменьшилась эрозия берегов. Случилось это потому, что 
влияние волков на оленей привело к взрывному росту деревьев и травы по 
берегам рек, что привело к их укреплению. Поменялась сама география парка, 
а все благодаря четырнадцати волкам, выпущенным туда менее двадцати лет 
назад.

http://mi3ch.livejournal.com/2709714.html﻿

top_comment.author: Jordan Clymer

comments.text:
Historic gray wolf range had them all the way down near the borders of 
Mexico. They definitely lived in Oregon. I think one of the largest impacts 
they'll have in Oregon is the balancing out of the coyote population. 
Currently there are these stupid "coyote derbys" and other contests in 
parts of oregon on who can bring in the most coyote ears. This is stupid 10 
different ways, but I'll point out why on two of the bigger reasons:

Killing a coyote alpha female makes the other females in the pack go into 
heat. So hey, everyone else gets to have litters of pups!

Litters become larger as these pack-oriented animals try to compensate for 
lost numbers

Wolves and coyotes are natural enemies. While they technically do not 
occupy the same ecological niche, wolves will not share their territory 
with coyotes. As pointed out in the video, wolves will have a better impact 
on controlling the population of coyotes than any poisoning, trapping, and 
hunting will. 

Coyotes are some of the biggest assholes for ranchers (oh hey, fun fact 
time - domesticated dogs kill a ton of livestock too). Coyotes are smart, 
and also lazy hunters. If they get the idea they like sheep, they'll figure 
out all the deterrents that a rancher will use. Wolves are much more likely 
to maintain a purely wild-meat diet, and are more likely to avoid 
visual/audible deterrents that ranchers put up. That's not to say that 
wolves won't prey on livestock. They can and do. But statistically 
speaking, the neighbor's pack of dogs, or coyotes, pose larger threats. If 
and when a wolf gets a taste for farm-raised meat, I don't see an issue 
with culling one or two bad apples from the pack that make a nuisance out 
of themselves. It's unfortunate to do so, but we also treat other larger 
predators who lose their fear of humans the same way (such as bears who get 
a taste for garbage cans/civilization)

TLDR - I think wolves in Oregon will be fine, with intelligent and trained 
people at the head of any reintroduction effort.

comments.text:
+John Wise
No, I can't, not without a lot of study.  I can say that the video presents 
a lot of anecdotal evidence and while it's nicely done, where is the hard 
data to support his assertions?  I'm not claiming to know otherwise, I'm 
suggesting that these sorts of claims can be made by anyone and without 
peer review, they're specious. 

This sort of topic is such that everyone wants to believe the conclusions 
because of our bias.  That is not a helpful attitude if we are to  
understand the interconnectedness of things.  It's just a video, no 
reference notes, no sources, nada.

The true test would be to remove the wolves again in another 100 years and 
see what happens.  Removing the wolf was mankind tinkering, reintroducing 
them after 70 years could also be considered tinkering.

Based on chaos theory, one could posit that in another 200 years, the 
entire system could fail simply because the wolves were reintroduced today, 
even though in the meantime, the system thrived early on due to the 
reintroduction.

Don't take my skepticism as being anti-wolf.  I'm just saying...

now, i love animals and have never killed a predator. but it always amazes 
me how environmentalists change the facts to bolster their case. the fact 
is there were always wolves in Yellowstone. the introduction of the 
Canadian Grey wolf into Yellowstone was litigated under the Endangered 
Species Act and it was proven that act wiped out the native Yellowstone 
wolf. In addition, the expanded wolf population has decimated other species 
in the park. These "deer" as the narrator called them are the elk herds 
that used to roam the park. Wolves are pack animals and when the pack is 
successful the wolves get "blood lust" which is killing for killings sake. 
Elk herds in and around Yellowstone were virtually wiped out by the wolves 
in their blood lust. That was the real reason there was a trophic cascade. 
Then they turned to coyotes. Finally the wolf packs are starving due to a 
lack of prey and are sick and dying from fleas. Nature, it seems, is taking 
back what man thought was best.﻿

comments.text:
+Ed Price I do not have time to debate with you if you cannot grasp a basic 
concept. The wolf population will not soar and decimate wildlife. Prior to 
Europeans "discovering" America, did wolves eat all of the available prey? 
And yes, nature does balance if left alone. There are annual fluctuations, 
but things average out. Please read this article 
http://www.conservationnw.org/what-we-do/predators-and-prey/carnivores-predators-and-their-prey 
(scroll down about half way to the "Predators & prey: Wolves and 
white-tails" section) and try to digest this:

There are 3,000 wolves in Minnesota. They eat on average about 50,000 of 
the estimated 450,000 white-tailed deer a year. This represents about 11.5 
% of the deer population, with minimal supplements of snowshoe hares, 
beavers, and moose.
...

The research showed that doe mortality from wolves ranged from 4% to 22% 
per year but most typically was between 5% to 10% per year with the highest 
rate observed in the very severe winter of 1995-96.

Despite the fact that deer outnumber wolves in Minnesota by 150 to 1, 
wolves are not particularly effective hunters of white-tails.

According to the MDNR, “Wolves end up surviving primarily on the most 
vulnerable individuals in the deer population, such as very young, old, 
sick, injured, or nutritionally compromised deer, because those are the 
ones they can catch. The result being, that under certain conditions…many 
of the deer that wolves kill likely would have died from other causes, such 
as starvation or disease.”

Biologists refer to such predation impacts as “compensatory” as opposed to 
the “additive” effects of human hunters, who kill most prey in the prime of 
their reproductive lives.

+Green Moon Art Yes, the predator population will soar in the presence of 
no predators for themselves and lots of food. After it soars, food will get 
scarcer, so they will start eating other, less choice prey. All kinds of 
prey will decline, causing the predator populations to decline. Honestly, 
if you can't follow this, you are not equipped to be bothering us 
here. Don't try to confuse the issue by asking about sharks in the sea or 
the birds with lasers. That's not a thought experiment, that's just 
wandering. Nature is never balanced, it is a constant act of re-balancing; 
external inputs cause oscillations that take a while to smooth out, and 
usually before it does smooth out, another input zonks the balance again.

comments.text:
+ntanner77 Yes and no. Introducing predators into a food-rich environment, 
and especially with no predators of its own to fear, those predators will 
flourish. Indeed, they will explode. About then, you notice something; 
where are all the deer? Oops, really, really down. Now, how do you protect 
those deer? If you don't do anything, the deer population will drop so low 
that the predators have to switch to something else, like maybe bear cubs 
and beavers. Pressure gets put on those species, until the wolves start to 
starve. Don't you see that, along this continuum, you will be hearing 
screams from the Friends of the Deer, the beavers, the bears, and finally 
even the Wolves (we must supplement the starving wolf population!) 
Everybody will scream if the suggestion is made that some wolves must be 
killed. So, my point simply is; the author is too gleeful about seeing 
wolves introduced into this park environment without considering the 
consequences.  Sure, wolves were always a part of this ecosystem; 
re-introducing them after the ecosystem became unbalanced will result in 
several oscillations of the balance, and we better be ready for the special 
interest groups to begin screaming when their favored flora or fauna gets 
screwed in one of those oscillatory extremes.

comments.author: Roman Schwendtmayer

comments.text:
+ironblud Humans do not act "contrary to evolution" (even if some deny 
evolution). Evolution is a process, and whatever humans do is simply one 
part of that process. If humans choose to level the hills and fill the 
valleys of Yellowstone, that will simply be one (huge) input to what 
evolution does. Elk and deer may well disappear, bit gophers and rats might 
well then take over.
Also, evolution does not simply favor the strong. Strength is just one 
factor in an organism's success. Speed, foraging efficiency, temperature 
tolerance and intelligence are some other factors that can be more 
important than strength. Evolution favors the organism that is most 
successful at the moment; change the environmental inputs and that organism 
may die off entirely.
Your argument that the only thing that matters to a species is 
self-preservation is interesting. How would you explain having a park like 
Yellowstone to be relevant to the self-preservation of humans? Shouldn't we 
be using that land to our maximum advantage, either as an energy source or 
as crop land? (I already know the answer, but do you?)
comments.author: Ed Price

comments.text:
+Paradoxarn I only know my experiences.  I can't speak for others. 
 Although I have seen many others suffer as well and heard too many sad 
stories told to me in confidence.  

Maybe it bothers me more with humans because we like to claim we are 
intelligent and have a moral conscience.  So we are supposed to know 
better, but we do bad things anyway.  You can't blame an animal for 
following its instincts to survive.  That's all they know.  Humans are 
supposed to be intelligent, but still fall back on mob mentality.  Why?
comments.author: Cynical Cthulhu

comments.text:
+Cynical Cthulhu I see, so you just pointed to YouTube-comments as an 
example. Yet your life-experience is not much better since it may very well 
be the case that other's have had the opposite experience not to speak of 
the subjective nature of personal experience. 

Epistemology aside however, your allegation is that humanity is cruel, 
selfish and stupid. Let's look at each of your charges in turn.

Is humanity cruel? Obviously cruel humans exist but I find it hard to think 
they are a majority, most people have friends and family who they care 
about and many would not turn away strangers who ask for help. Moreover we 
don't just care about other humans, we tend to love our pets, we admire the 
wild animals and we even feed animals who aren't pet's or livestock such as 
birds. When we hurt others we seem to feel compelled to find a 
justification, something which implies that cruelty is not something we 
like or is part of our natural tendencies. Lastly nature is cruel, so why 
would it be a problem if humanity is cruel since you surely don't have a 
problem with other animals causing each other suffering and harm?

Selfishness is again something which there is no lack of in nature and as I 
described when speaking of human cruelty, it seems the opposite is the 
case. Altruism in other species rarely extend beyond the boundaries of the 
species or the group, yet this seems to be frequent of humans.

Lastly, I find the idea that humanity is stupid patently absurd. Are we not 
the most intelligent species on the planet? Perhaps you meant to speak of 
ignorance but if so, why the despair? Are we not expanding the limits of 
what we know and do we not learn from our mistakes? In this area I would 
think that there is the most reason to have hope. 

If I had believed that humanity was cruel, selfish and stupid and thought 
that to be reason to denounce it then I can't imagine the hate I would feel 
to the rest of nature.
comments.author: Paradoxarn

comments.text:
+Ate Scaladferri I wasn't implying that you said anything like that. Your 
conversation has been banter and not insults. I do want to make one last 
comment to you. Please read it with an open mind. I have never said that I 
am against the wolf reintroduction. What I will say is that I support 
conservation. I want my children and grandchildren for generations. What I 
hope that people don't do is jump to uneducated opinion about how to do so 
in areas that are foreign to them. I am a conservationist also, in my own 
way. I do not like the way that the wolf was reintroduced, but I appreciate 
that it was. One thing that I haven't said is that I was 25 meters from a 
wolf with my gun drawn and could have legally shot it. What changed my mind 
was that I saw that she was obviously a mother. She was taking food back to 
her pups. I didn't shoot because I would not do that with any animal. I 
later heard the pups attempting to howl with joy after having eaten. It 
made me smile because I love and appreciate nature. I will always listen to 
multiple points of view because I know that everything has a consequence. I 
see the consequence of this is a lot of areas. I have personal, close 
experience with the consequence of wolves. I do not want to forget about 
all of the aspects of how wolves affect the area. Please learn to respect 
and appreciate others thoughts, feelings and expertise on topics without 
being emotional. It will serve you well.
comments.author: Mike Munn

Yellowstone Nat'l Park, images of elk are displayed, which can lead to some 
confusion: does the narrator mean that the wolves have reduced the deer 
population, elk population, or overall deer population (deer + elk + 
moose)? Furthermore, in the video the narrator uses the term "deer calves."

top_comment.text:
Когда в 1995 году четырнадцать волков были выпущены на волю в 
Йеллоустонском национальном парке, ученые и не подозревали, что это 
кардинально изменит всю экосистему парка.

Волков не было в парке 70 лет и все это время там царствовали олени, 
которые за годы бесконтрольного размножения (все усилия людей по контролю 
их популяции не приносили успеха) нанесли сильнейший урон местной флоре. 
Четырнадцать волков, конечно, не смогли съесть всех оленей, но они 
заставили тех осторожнее выбирать места для пастбищ и избегать некоторых 
участков парка. На тех местах начала возрождаться растительность. За шесть 
лет количество деревьев увеличилось в пять раз. Появились бобры, которым 
деревья нужны для постройки плотин. В заводях завелись ондатры, утки и 
рыбы. Волки уменьшили популяцию шакалов, что привело к увеличению 
количества зайцев и мышей, а те в свою сторону привлекли в парк ястребов, 
хорьков и лис. В парк пришли медведи, так как они смогли отгонять волков от 
их добычи или доедать их объедки. В парке увеличилось количество ягод.

Но самое удивительное, волки изменили течение рек. Их русла выпрямились и 
стабилизировались, уменьшилась эрозия берегов. Случилось это потому, что 
влияние волков на оленей привело к взрывному росту деревьев и травы по 
берегам рек, что привело к их укреплению. Поменялась сама география парка, 
а все благодаря четырнадцати волкам, выпущенным туда менее двадцати лет 
назад.

http://mi3ch.livejournal.com/2709714.html﻿

impressive is it?  That's after 26 years.  Now we're suppose to believe 
that wolves, and very few of them, have killed enough animals to stop

erosion and thus allowing the rivers to change direction.  Seriously?﻿
top_comment.author: 2coolhipdude

comments.text:
+Isis4211   Sorry you can't understand that I agree with you.  What you are 
failing to grasp, is that this video used natural regrowth after a massive 
fire to perpetuate a theory that wolves were the "sole" cause of the 
change.  They weren't and it's more likely they didn't even contribute 
.001% to the changes seen at Yellowstone.
comments.author: 2coolhipdude

comments.text:
It's not too far to think that the reintroduction of an integral part of an 
ecosystem will rebalance it. I can not see how, other than not being very 
detailed, this video is not factual. I could see how you might be misled to 
think the video is implying, but I would say that is due to the video's 
summation of events and lack of proper detail. I think when many grazers 
are taken out of an area (among other things), succession can happen very 
rapidly. With my advisor's work in the nearby experimental forest, I have 
seen what just 15 years of no (or fewer) whitetail deer can do to the 
herbaceous layer only. It was nearly unbelievable had there not been 
photographs of it. It is not unimaginable, however.
comments.author: Isis4211

comments.text:
+Isis4211
You are correct.  If the video was titled "Rebirth of Yellowstone After the

So lovely to see  how Mother Nature balances Herself. It would be safe to 
say that without man's intervention (in general), nature  holds Her own 
balance. It would seem logical that their "instincts" are what drives their 
behavior and resultant changes. It would also seem that at large, man has 
lost access to "natural instincts", such as being able to differentiate 
from the desire to drink water vs coffee, tea, and soda. Or the desire to 
eat real food instead of chemically laden, processed, poisonous garbage. 
And, the instinct to know when our behavior is destabilizing the natural 
infrastructure that allows our own survival.

What will the imbalance we are causing attract as a balancing force? Do we 
need to turn Grizzly bears loose in major cities, or encourage TV 
programming that focuses on things we all need to know about how to live in 
balance with the earth and simple tips for doing that?

Much chi,
Paul Chek
Holistic Health Practitioner
Founder, C.H.E.K Institute﻿

comments.text:
+Torsten Zeband Wölfe sind sehr scheu und haben große Angst vor den 
Menschen, der männliche Jäger ist der einzige Feind des Wolfes.
Wölfe schlagen eigentlich nur kranke oder schwache Tiere, weil sonst die 
Gefahr verletzt zu werden zu groß wäre, so haben sie auch einen großen 
Nutzen für das Gleichwicht in der Natur, siehe Yellowstone.
Wenn du einen Wolf begegnest , dann ist das Zufall, bleib einfach ruhig, 
kann mir nicht vorstellen, dass er dir Nahe kommen wird, dafür hat er viel 
zu große Angst, wird dich aber neugierig beobachten :)
Nur ein kranker Einzelgänger könnte wahrscheinlich eine Gefahr werden, aber 
mach mal eine Rechersche im Internet, so etwas kommt so gut wie nie vor.
Der Wolf hat ein falsches Image, er ist einfach ein wunderbares, 
faszinierendes Wesen.
comments.author: Andi Wolf

comments.text:
OK, wenn du mit Wölfen gelebt hast, dann sag mir bitte: Was tue ich am 
besten, wenn ich beim Pilze suchen auf einen Wolf treffe? Treffe ich 
überhaupt einen oder hat der mehr Angst vor mir als ich vor ihm?
Weil, wenn ich mir diverse Dokus über Wölfe angesehen habe, dann war die 
Kernaussage, die im Gedächtnis bleibt: "Das sind Raubtiere, Fleischfresser, 
Jäger, gefährlich. Auch wenn ich mit ihnen lebe und sie mich kennen, darf 
ich nicht hinfallen, das wäre fatal." Und gefüttert werden sie auch immer 
durch einen Zaun.
Also bin ich erstmal vorsichtig und glaube lieber an den "bösen" Wolf, 
bevor ich selber gebissen/gegessen werde.
Liege ich falsch?
comments.author: Torsten Zeband

Meiner Meinung nach, hat der Wolf in DE so gut wie keine Chance, dafür 
wurde das Image schon zu sehr verdreht.
Der beste Schutz gegen Wölfe wäre ein Esel, die haben keine Furcht vor

comments.text:
Möglich, ich hab selber keine Schafe. Entschädigung ist gut und schön, 
irgendwoher muss aber auch dieses Geld kommen. Und spätestens wenn du 2 - 3 
mal als Schäfer/Bauer betroffen warst, hast du die Nase voll vom 
Entschädigung beantragen. Außerdem könnte ich mir vorstellen, dass die 
restliche Herde ziemlichem Stress ausgesetzt ist, wenn plötzlich ein Rudel 
oder einzelner Wolf angreift und mitten unter denen eines reißt. Bei 
Schweinen spricht man davon, dass durch diesen Stress das Fleisch an 
Geschmack verliert, wird dann dadurch nicht bei Schafen ebenfalls die 
Qualität der ganzen Herde beeinträchtigt? Ich weiß es nicht, ist nur so ein 
quergedachter Gedanke.
Und wenn früh halb sieben ein Wolf mitten im Dorf steht, wenn die Kinder 
zur Schule gehen, dann ist mir nicht ganz wohl dabei. Auch wenn es "damals" 
bei uns im Dorf nur ein ganz kleiner war.
Nicht falsch verstehen: Es ist ganz toll anzusehen und zu hören, wie sich 
die Natur durch die Wölfe verändert hat. Aber das ist IM YELLOWSTONE PARK, 
der ist auch ein paar Quadratkilometer größer als die Wälder zwischen den 
bewohnten Orten bei uns. Da haben sie Platz und werden nicht durch die 
Anwesenheit von Menschen und deren Behausungen gestört.
comments.author: Torsten Zeband

I don't think it was claimed in the video that wolves were "magic saviours

comments.author: WorldByTheTale

comments.text:
+Sustainable Human It is interesting that the huge fires that were the 
first test of the "let it burn" philosophy on are not mentioned. Natural 
recovery from the fires that burned more than 1/3 of the park in 1988 would 
also have contributed. Environmental science would get more main stream 
credibility if rather than cherry picking the results, an actual unbiased 
study was the goal. Did wolves help control the elk? Quite possibly. Are 
they magic saviours of nature? Most likely not, they are, like us, just 
part of a big system that we still are not even close to understanding. I 
do applaud the results of this video in showing the wonders that are in 
Yellowstone, and hopefully convincing people to take time away from their 
computers and go outside and experience the amazing things that are all 
around us.

top_comment.text:
I remember when wolves were re-introduced to the Yellowstone National 
Park... I supported it by writing letters and "adopting" wolves. It was 
exciting to hear about the wolves' population growth and how they helped 
balance the deer population. It is not surprising to me that the ripple 
effect occurred after the deer population was balanced and their movement 
patterns were changed. Everything on Earth is connected and should be 
treated with respect. This belief is one of the reasons I identify so much 
with Native Americans. Of course, overpopulation of ANY species, including 
the wolf, has negative consequences to the environment, so obviously the 
park has to monitor the wolf population. From what I've read and seen in 
documentaries, things are still going very well there. YAY Yellowstone!! :-)
P.S.
Rae Rae P., this post and all of its wolf howling is dedicated to you! :-D﻿

Ecosystem - How Wolves Change Rivers 
In 1995, wolves were re-introduced into the Yellowstone National Park, 
after being wolf-free for 70 years. What naturalists and biologist never 
imagined, was that the most remarkable thing would take place. Mother 
Nature knows what she’s doing if we just leave her alone.﻿

top_comment.text:
Visit http://sustainableman.org/ to explore the world of sustainability.

For more from George Monbiot, visit http://www.monbiot.com/ and for more on 
"rewilding" visit http://bit.ly/1hKGemK and/or check out George Monbiot's 
book Feral: rewilding the land, the sea and human life: 
http://amzn.to/1fjgirx

NOTE: There are "elk" pictured in this video when the narrator is referring 
to "deer." This is because the narrator is British and the British word for 
"elk" is "red deer" or "deer" for short. The scientific report this is 
based on refers to elk so we wanted to be accurate with the truth of the 
story.

"When we try to pick out anything by itself, we find it hitched to 
everything else in the Universe." - John Muir

When wolves were reintroduced to Yellowstone National Park in the United 
States after being absent nearly 70 years, the most remarkable "trophic 
cascade" occurred. What is a trophic cascade and how exactly do wolves 
change rivers? George Monbiot explains in this movie remix.


Narration from TED: "For more wonder, rewild the world" by George Monbiot. 
Watch the full talk, here: http://bit.ly/N3m62h

B-Roll Credits:

"Yellowstone" (http://bit.ly/1bPI6DM)
"Howling Wolves - Heulende Wölfe" (http://bit.ly/1c2Oidv)
"Fooled by Nature: Beaver Dams" (http://bit.ly/NGgQSU)

Music Credits:

Chris Zabriskie (http://bit.ly/1c2uckW)

This video was edited by Steve Agnos with editorial assistance from Chris

+Sunyata I prefer to live in a world where humans respect the role of all 
creatures and not just the ones that don't inconvenience us. When 
discussing the semantics of 'balance' it is simple. It's a situation where 
many species compliment the existence of others. When there is an explosion 
of population in nature (this is common) it is not often sustainable and it 
usually balanced out. Humans can't exploit the natural system without the 
earth taking back eventually. A lifetime for us is a few moments for the 
planet. Humans, as large mammals may find things will get more difficult 
with time. Of course, for most of humanity it already is. Climate 
issues,resources management and population growth should be at the 
forefront of discussions today but most leaders can't see beyond their 
terms.

top_comment.text:
Increíble explicación sobre la influencia del lobo en la cadena trófica. 
Para los que no sepan inglés, os explico: el lobo se introduce en 
Yellowstone en 1995. El lobo provoca que el ciervo (su presa principal) se 
retire de las riveras de los ríos, donde es más vulnerable. Esto provoca 
que la vegetación se recupere en estas zonas, aumentando el número y el 
tamaño de los árboles, lo cual genera nuevos espacios para especies 
pequeñas, lo cual beneficia a otras especies (como castores, que aprovechan 
la madera, u osos, que devoran las bayas). Toda la cadena trófica se 
beneficia de la presencia del depredador. Y lo más increíble de todo: los 
árboles en las riveras asientan el terreno, por lo que contienen mejor el 
curso de los ríos: el lobo también cambia la misma geografía de 
Yellowstone. ﻿
top_comment.author: Juan Luis Fernández Gallo

comments.text:
+Sergio Perea No te preocupes, estoy acostumbrado a que me odien todos los 
bandos :D
De todas maneras, hay que tener en cuenta que Yellowstone es un espacio 
enorme y sin poblaciones humanas, donde es posible que la introducción de 
una especie como el lobo ayude a restablecer un equilibrio trófico de forma 
natural. En otras zonas más pequeñas, y sobre todo con alta densidad de 
población, la introducción del lobo me parece inviable, o muy complicada. 
Medidas como la caza muy controlada de especies depredadoras me puede 
parecer, en determinados casos, un mal necesario, sobre todo cuando la 
cadena trófica está desequilibrada. La alteración de ecosistemas por parte 
del hombre convierte al hombre, queramos o no, en el único gestor con 
capacidad de mantener con vida a las especies amenazadas en determinados 
ecosistemas, y creo que es responsabilidad nuestra hacerlo con todos los 
medios a nuestro alcance. Creo que con esto ya he conseguido que me odien 
también los ecologistas... así me va la vida :D
