top_comment.text:
This is an excellent example of wolf propaganda but has no actual basis in 
facts or logic. I ask anyone who believes in this to please simply apply 
some rational thought to this process expressed in this movie. I believe if 
you think it through and don't simply follow what you are being told you 
will come to a completely separate conclusion. ﻿
top_comment.author: Eddy Howard

comments.text:
+Michelle Steinmeyer
Hi Michelle,

These are great points and you are right of course on the attacks on humans 
it has not happened as of yet. However there are numerous accounts of close 
calls and they are growing more in frequency. This is no fault of the wolf 
or the humans it is simply a matter of humans enjoying the outdoors and 
being in closer proximity to wolves. Only time will tell if attacks will 
happen. I hope it never does.

As far as elk numbers I ask you to look at the latest elk census taken 
after the wolves have begun to migrate into the area where the elk live. 
Please look at the reports from the state biologists reports from Wyoming, 
Idaho, and Montana. Idaho currently has 650 wolves in residence and the elk 
population has been reduced significantly. Such so that the state is now 
spending $2,000,000 to reduce the numbers of wolves in hopes of reviving 
the elk populations. Well they were but wolf conservation groups have taken 
legal action to try and block these effort. Elk numbers were at their 
highest before the introduction of wolves and have done nothing but drop 
since the arrival of the wolves. This is not a fault of over hunting but is 
a direct result of wolf predation. For a fun time look up elk populations 
in the western united states from 15 years ago then look up the same data 
from 2 years ago. If you overlay them you will see the numbers are way way 
down. Now overlay the known wolf ranges and you can see very quickly that 
prey animals drastically suffer when wolves move into the area.

In my humble opinion to few elk is any number smaller then what the natural 
habitat can carry. I want the maximum number of prey animals per square 
mile that any ecosystem can carry.

I believe that wolves have the right to exist but not at the detriment of 
other animals. If you reduce the prey animals you reduce hunting which in 
turn reduces the amount of money going into the conservation effort. The 
reason that hunting is reduced is simply because hunters will not allow 
more animals to be taken then an area can carry. We want more animals next 
year. It is not about the challenge of the hunt but the betterment of the 
species. When these animals are taken by wolves money is lost I don't know 
how to put it better. I don't know why conservation groups would risk 
losing 1.2 billion dollars in revenue by simply introducing wolves. The 
money prey animals that are around to be hunted the more tags can be sold 
and thus the more money is generated. If this money is lost how will it be 
recouped. Will we have to start charging for access to public lands? I 
surely hope not.
comments.author: Eddy Howard

comments.text:
+Eddy Howard Eddie,  I do have to comment on the possibility of wolves 
attacking humans.  There is not a known documented case of a wolf killing a 
human in North America.  There are a few unresolved whether it was a bear 
or wolf.  Wolves by nature are very fearful of humans, unlike coyotes and 
such.  I think they get a bad rap due the fables and folklore like Little 
Red Riding Hood.  More elk attack humans than wolves.

Another point I don't necessarily agree is that the reintroduction of 
wolves kills tens of thousands of prey animals. In YP the 89 wolves killed 
159 elk out of 255 kills. I realize in ID, MT and other states there are 
300-400 wolves, I still don't see how that translates into tens of 
thousands of prey animals.

Conversely, are we allowing too many to be hunted? I don't know. And what 
is too few elk?  Is it solely driven by the supply for hunters and ease of 
hunting vs a more challenging hunt when numbers are lower?

Eddy, you are so right when it comes to the funds spent by the two 
sides fighting when the ultimate goal is the same.  Imagine what we could 
do together and with those types of monies. I believe in the rights of 
hunters, I have concern for ranchers livelihoods (heck, I eat their steaks 
etc) and I believe in a wolf's intrinsic right to exists in its natural 
territory.
comments.author: Michelle Steinmeyer

comments.text:
+Marvin Jayson
Hi Marvin,

I think we can agree to disagree on the trophic cascade affect. I would be 
more apt to believe it if the problem had been brought up before the 
introduction of the wolves instead of after. If this really were the issue 
then I believe that Yellowstone should have been in peril during the 70+ 
years that the wolves weren't there. But that being said for the sake of 
argument if this problem did exist shouldn't the decision making process 
have went something like this:

Problem: The Yellowstone ecosystem is running 20% under what it could be.

Proposed Solution: Introduce wolves back into the environment to bring this 
back to where it should be.

Pros:
1) With the introduction of wolves in the park they will regulate the 
overgrazing and bring the Yellowstone ecosystem back to optimal levels of 
interaction.

Cons:
1) Introduction of wolves will kill thousands or tens of thousands of prey 
animals which will impact the surrounding areas financially. This will 
drastically decrease the amount of monies available to these areas which 
help with habitat management and game law enforcement.

2) Wolves will not stay within the borders of the park and will expand 
their territory preying on livestock thus becoming a burden to ranchers in 
that area. The compensation for loses suffered by this predation will be 
significant and will be paid from money generated by tax payer dollars.

3) Wolves are opportunistic predators and will prey on any food source 
available. This means the loss of cows, sheep, horses, even family pets as 
their range expands. I am purposefully not bringing up attacks on humans 
but it is a possibility.

With this decision making process I don't believe that wolves would have 
been allowed back into any ecosystem. These are only a few of the reasons 
that states like Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming all vehemently denounced the 
reintroduction of the wolf.

That being said and like Michelle pointed out hunters and non hunters alike 
all want the exact same thing. The preservation of land for future 
generations to enjoy. To me this is the worse part of this entire wolf 
introduction. Shouldn't conservationist whether they be hunters or non 
hunters be working together to preserve land for future generations instead 
of fighting one another and wasting resources that could go toward the 
purchase of land that would do just that. I cringe to think how much money 
has been wasted when hunters and non hunters fight one another. In my mind 
the developers are just sitting back enjoying the show and hope everyone 
keeps distracted. I am sorry this is so short but I only have a few 
minutes. I really would love to keep discussing this and hopefully we can 
understand one another better.

To WoodSprout I am sorry but I wasn't very clear. I don't want to hunt 
Yellowstone, (well I kind of do now that you brought it up :). I was simply 
asking if all affects of the wolf introduction had been brought up and 
thought about.
comments.author: Eddy Howard

comments.text:
+Eddy Howard Eddy I appreciate the dialogue and I want to understand other 
points of view.  Your point 1 disagreement, I didn't mean to insinuate that 
the elk pop hasn't decrease, it has.  What is the proper population for 
Yellowstone, that I don't know.  However, last year 89 wolves killed 159 
elk, I don't think they are entirely responsible for the decline. If the 
tropic cascade is true, then the wolves have an indirect relationship with 
the increase in the bear population. But I still don't see both species are 
responsible for such a decline. Should the decline be studied and managed 
absolutely.  But I don't think eradicating wolves in the answer (not that 
you suggested it). Again, what is the proper elk population for 
Yellowstone? I can't find anything on it. 

For point # 2, I profess I don't know much about hunting.  I have friends 
that are hunters but I don't know the details.  I just see mounted animals 
on the walls :-)  I have a healthy respect for hunters, the deer herds here 
still need more culling.

Regarding are the current wolves in YP; are they native to Yellowstone? yes 
as species they are, the Gray Wolf, Canus Lupus, as a subspecies no. The 
wolves released are Mackenzie Valley Wolves vs the original Rocky Mountain 
sub species.  There is a whole other debate about sub-species.  The 
Mackenzie Valley are slightly larger but as far as aggression, I'm not sure 
what you mean.  They kill only when hungry, they are not random killers 
just to kill.  And yes, Yellowstone ecosystem began to have a noticeable 
change a few years after the wolves vanished. As an example, beaver were 
almost non existent until the return of the wolves.

I do believe hunters love animals and wildlife, I know people can 
generalize and attached labels but just because someone hunts doesn't mean 
the don't like wildlife including predators.

Another animal that is still in peril in YP is the Moose but that has more 
to do with the huge fire of 1988 which burned about 45% of the park. 

thanks for the thought provoking dialogue
comments.author: Michelle Steinmeyer

comments.text:
Hi Eddy,

I also do apologize if my comment seemed aggressive.  As I was reading up 
yesterday, the key term was "reintroduction", as the wolves were extirpated 
in the 1920s. So I believe it was also their natural habitat.

Going back to the issue if the wolves were the right solution or not, and 
assuming that trophic cascades are indeed true (a lot of documentation 
supports it), then simply from a cause and effect standpoint, I believe the 
wolves were the right choice. As for the question if there really was a 
problem, if comparing the before and after effects and seeing which is 
better, again, I'd say the wolves were the right choice.

Assuming that the trophic cascade is real and is the impact of the wolves 
in this case, it's also possible that hunters wouldn't have had the same 
effect. Since the predator-prey relationship affects each other's behavior, 
let's say the wolf-elk, it also affects other animals, coyote, fox, 
scavengers, etc., then there's a risk that hunters wouldn't have that same 
effect. I hope that makes sense. Anyway, thanks for your replies.
comments.author: Marvin Jayson

comments.text:
+Michelle Steinmeyer
Hi Michelle,

I believe that every animal has a right to exist however they need to be 
managed. The difference between bears and wolves is significant while bears 
do eat elk calves, they don't only eat elk, deer, bison and so on. Coyotes 
do however they are much smaller and their impact is much less intrusive. 
This does bring up the point about whether or not these wolves that are 
relocated to Yellowstone are native to this area? As I understand it these 
wolves are much larger and more aggressive kind of like what you are seeing 
with the Anacondas down in Florida. No natural predators and an abundance 
of food. Great for the predator not so good for the prey. They only way to 
control predator numbers now is to wait for all the prey to be killed then 
the wolves to starve to death. This doesn't seem very logical to me.

The overall question I keep asking myself and the one that never seems to 
be answered is what problem were we solving? I did not realize that 
Yellowstone had an issue with overgrazing, or low numbers of beavers, or 
small number of foxes, or less then adequate numbers of migratory birds, so 
on and so on. If I am mistaken please let me know. The Yellowstone I knew 
was a utopia of wildlife diversity found few other places on earth. We 
decided to "improve" on that by introducing the wolves back into the 
ecosystem. To me this is a case of meddling just because we can.

I do disagree with you on a couple of points.

1: If the trees and grasses are coming back it is not because elk are less 
stationary it is simply because there are fewer and fewer of them left to 
browse. Let's call that what it is, to say that elk are eating less because 
they are running around to much seems very silly.

2: The second is scavenging for other animals. When a hunter kills not all 
of the animal is taken, usually the innards are left and if the pack out is 
difficult then the meat is removed from the bones and all the bones are 
left. This means there is a significant amount of food for all other 
animals. In fact if you want to find out if a hunter has been successful 
simply look for the coyotes, crows, and other scavengers in that area.

I really do appreciate you replying back to me. My goal is not to convince 
you to hunt or that I hate wolves. My hope is that people will begin to see 
why this is upsetting to the sportsperson. Contrary to popular belief we 
love our prey animals and are fanatical about them. I know this seems 
counter intuitive but trust me we do. Imagine what would happen if you 
spent billions of dollars restoring herds, purchasing habitat, and 
countless millions of hours trying to preserve something for future 
generations only to have an opposing agenda introduce something that 
counteracts all your efforts. It is completely demoralizing and 
heartbreaking. Once again thanks for the reply.
comments.author: Eddy Howard

comments.text:
+Eddy Howard Thanks for the dialogue. I want to understand why you don't 
think wolves have the right to exist in their native territory? Elk have 
the right to exist.  Grizzly feed on elk calves, should they be removed 
from the park?  I agree hunting helps manage over population. Where I live 
has a huge population of deer.   However, if hunting was used in an attempt 
to correct over gazing and its affect in YP then you would not have the 
trophic cascade.  Allot of animals scavenge on wolf kills, such as bears, 
birds, fox etc. which the numbers have increase since their arrival and so 
on.  As well, part of the regrowth of the valleys is not because of herd 
reduction but because of fear of the wolf. Elk, bison, deer don't linger 
due to the fear of wolves. This would not happen with hunts.
comments.author: Michelle Steinmeyer

comments.text:
+Marvin Jayson
HI Marvin, I apologize if it seems I am being aggressive this is not my 
intention at all. In fact I am hoping to generate an ongoing civil dialogue 
with people who support the introduction of wolves so that I can better 
understand their logic. I would never blast anyone for having an opinion or 
belief in this matter. It simply seems illogical to me to try and solve the 
"problem" of prey over population with the introduction of wolves. If there 
really was an issue with this wouldn't it make more sense to solve this 
problem by letting responsible tax paying sportsman harvest these animals? 
The benefits of this would be that sportsman would be able to feed their 
families unprocessed food and the public would benefit from the millions of 
dollars that would be generated from such an interaction. If humans had 
dispatched as many animals as these wolves have I seriously doubt the 
support would be the same. If the problem is over population why not find a 
solution that is both economically benefiting and provides a finer quality 
of life for those who participate? I believe you can see why I am so 
confused by this logic of introducing an apex predator that benefits no-one.
comments.author: Eddy Howard

comments.text:
Watched it, read up a bit more and it seems many do concur with the 
phenomenon, "trophic cascade", and there are more examples in nature. As 
the video said, the introduction of wolves in Yellowstone Park is a classic 
example, and it's well documented. I found lots of articles. Though, I 
think the point of this video is balance in nature, and for this particular 
instance, it's about the wolves. Going back to your comment, I'm now 
applying rational thought and I'd say what is being said in the video, it 
makes sense to me. It may be wolf propaganda, but even so, I think it's 
true. I've heard and read that wolves are overpopulated in some areas, and 
I think this also applies to them, like how it applied in this case of the 
overpopulated deer/elk. So now, I'm just wondering if you're gonna blast me 
now that I have reached my own conclusion, which is different from yours. 
Well, no pun intended.
comments.author: Marvin Jayson

comments.text:
+woodsprout
Hi woodsprout, not sure which facts you would like me to point out when I 
am simply asking you to apply logic when watching this film. There are 
several inaccuracies that are glaring but I do not want to influence you in 
your way of thinking. Some things to think about though are that most of 
these "facts" that are quoted in this piece have never been printed or even 
hypothesized. The one "fact" that I do know of is that beavers are making a 
"comeback" in Yellowstone. Which is fine I suppose however to trade an 
abundance of beavers for the decimation of thousands of elk, deer, moose, 
bison etc etc etc seems a bit extreme. However please make your own 
judgement. I am simply asking you to use common sense and think. Do you 
really believe the introduction of the wolves actually has the ability to 
change the course of rivers. It appears to me that the introduction of 
wolves is and will continue to be a mistake. Now we are trying to justify 
it by heralding a solution to a problem that never existed. But again this 
is my opinion, please think for yourself is all I ask.
comments.author: Eddy Howard

comments.text: How about you give some examples instead of merely throw doubt.

*The Beauty of Nature and Hidden Talent of Wolves*

Its incredible how reintroducing wolves to Yellowstone National Park 
changed the whole ecosystem and also played a huge part in bringing more 
wildlife back into the area. It just shows each and every animal plays a 
big part in our eco-system. 

Wolves are often given bad press and this video has certainly opened up my 
eyes to the amazing power of these animals. 

Have a Great Weekend Everyone and Enjoy the Beauty of Nature! :)

Video on behalf of +Sustainable Human

+Steven Swaks The apex predator in an ecosystem is the keystone of that 
ecosystem, remove it and the arch falls. You could remove some of the 
herbivores and it wouldn't affect much, except the migration of a different

without the apex. And in this case, it was wolves. The same devastation is 
occurring in Africa with their lions and poachers.

+bitfreakazoid At one point or another everyone can see to one extent or 
another, some more then most, that humans are just down right destructive. 
Nature is only one thing that we have destroyed. Nature however does play a 
major role in us living as well. Without it, we have no food, water, or 
suitable environment. How smart is it to wipe something out because its for 
fashion? Or because we don't want to deal with the adjustment of another 
life?   
Change in innominate, there's no doubt about it. But we have taken very 
little, to no consideration about the consequences of what happens when we 
choose to alter our surroundings. In the end we are killing our future 
along with every other life we share on this planet.
I guess what I have to say to begin with is that ignorance is scary. It can 
be so dangerous. And the horrible thing about it is that there's too much 
of it in too many people. Which leads to people being cruel, stupid, or/and 
dangerous to themselves or others in nature, society, and life in general.

+UniversalPsyMind There is no lessening of damage, though. Even deer eat 
other animals for sustenance. All animals kill to eat, we just see it more 
with carnivores. Humans just happen to be the most destructive species and 
even feed their own with something they call meat, but is akin to mattress 
filler with watered-down antifreeze in it.

I can compare wheat to rabbits, you get way more food from rabbits than 
wheat, they reproduce much faster and eating them en mass causes no 
environmental damage as long as you don't over hunt. Which by Australia, 
you can see is not possible, they can't get rid of the horrid little pests 
and they are very invasive.

Your forest theory is interesting, but incorrect, and yet correct. A tree 
by itself has veins, a bloodstream with blood flowing through it, it has 
many mouths breathing in air and exhaling oxygen, and it has internal 
organs and systems that can be dissected piece by piece to show it is in 
fact a complete body just like you or me. But on to your theory of the 
forest being one organism, it is incorrect because the proportion is way 
off... The entire planet is a living organism.

The flora and fauna on its surface are microorganisms, the water is like 
the water in our bodies keeping everything liquid and living, in the oceans 
are enormous belts of water that circulate all water around the globe like 
a cardiovascular system, at its core the Earth has a constantly pulsating, 
gyrating orb of molten iron like a heart that beats, producing the 
electromagnetic field protecting us from radiation and other anomalies from 
space. And if you look at it as a whole, it functions just like any other 
larger organism. We just happen to be acting more like a disease than

comments.text:
+UniversalPsyMind Fast food is not food at all, it's poison. Free range 
animals are food, I cannot eat processed foods because they make me deathly 
ill. I lost 45 pounds in a matter of a few weeks by laying in bed all the 
time...just by getting rid of processed food in my diet. Industrial farming 
is torture, and it doesn't need to be. I like the wild meat the most but I 
do eat meat butchered from local places out here in the plains.

That is good that you get your B12, but I must admit it is distressing to 
hear that you think plants are not, alive, as it were, in the sense as 
animals. I am a passionate nature lover, and plants are in that category. 
One of the research documentaries I found was that even though they cannot 
move, plants react to the same exact stimuli as animals, they have the same 
hormonal reactions to pain as us, and they react to emotion better than us. 
That puts them at the same level of consciousness for me, but they are far 
superior in anatomy. You cut a carrot in half and plant it again, it will 
live and grow back. Cannot do that with a simpler life-form like an animal. 
This is my belief, I hold all life-forms as sacred.

I love wolves as the prime predators and keystones of ecological cycles 
around the world, and I live by their philosophy. I kill to eat, both plant 
and animal, I respect the land, and it takes care of me, and I try to do my 
part for the world even if it's a small part. For a wolf, it is a very big 
part that should never be allowed to recede to the damaged state it was at.
comments.author: Lycantis

population was at one point reduced to a handful of individuals and certain 
genetic abilities were lost including the production of some proteins  - 
damaged. Thus meat eating became acceptable among humans. Our ancestors 
recorded the tragic event at Gen 7:21-23. Animal genes were also reduced 
same way. Those taken in groups of seven remained Vegan, while those taken 
two-by-two (like canines - wolves) retained a shallower gene pool and 
became the predators. All are no longer vegan...

comments.text:
Here's the national park's list of reasoning behind the no dog rule.... Not 
one these reasons are valid. 

Restrictions on pets in parks are as much to protect your pet as to protect 
park resources. Following are some of the reasons parks give for regulating 
the presence of pets:
--When a loose pet chases a squirrel or raccoon, the wild animal's ability 
to survive is threatened, and when it is threatened, it may react 
aggressively.
--There is a strong possibility in parks such as Yellowstone that your pet 
could become prey for bear, coyote, owl, or other predators. 
--There is a possibility of exchange of diseases between domestic animals 
and wildlife. --Dogs, the most common traveling companion, are natural 
predators that may harass or even kill native wildlife that is protected 
within the park's boundaries.
--The "scent of a predator" that dogs leave behind can disrupt or alter the 
behavior of native animals. --Pets may be hard to control, even on a leash, 
within confines of often narrow park trails and may trample or dig up 
fragile vegetation. 
--Dog and cat feces add excessive nutrients and bacterial pollution to 
water, which decreases water quality and can also cause human health 
problems. 
--Finally, lost domestic animals sometimes turn to preying on park wildlife 
and must be destroyed.

top_comment.text:
And now I want to share with you one of the most interesting short videos 
I've seen in a while. It's about the idea of *trophic cascades:* how a 
small change to an ecosystem can lead to tremendous consequences. In this 
case, the change was the reintroduction of wolves to Yellowstone in the 
1990's, after a 70-year absence.

The direct effects of the wolves were small: the wolves eat a few deer, but 
apart from that mostly keep to themselves. But the indirect effects were 
huge.

It started because the deer, who had been running roughshod over the entire 
park, quickly figured out that places like valleys were *not good places* 
to be a deer when there are wolves about. This led to trees being able to 
grow in those areas for the first time in decades.

The effects of that are complex and profound, and I encourage you to watch 
the video, because I can't possibly summarize it better than it does. 
Everything from the animals to the plants to the very physical geography of 
the rivers was changed. 

The key lesson of this is that ecosystems are connected. You can't make a 
single change to one and expect it not to have consequences, including very 
far-reaching ones of a sort you couldn't ever have predicted. This is a 
general property of all large, strongly-interacting systems, including 
societies, and it's worth keeping in mind whenever things change.﻿
top_comment.author: Yonatan Zunger

comments.text:
In the Wallace Fire of 1910 or 1911(
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Fire_of_1910) 3 million acres of the 
Northwest burned, blanketing the east coast of the US with smoke for 
weeks.  It got the Forest Service animated about fire suppression.  Smokey 
the Bear came much later, but is part of the same mindset of not 
understanding that fire and wolves are a key part of ecosystems.  There is 
a parallel to financial markets that comes close to Minsky's work.  Fires 
(recessions and depressions) are a natural part of the financial 
ecosystem.  After 70 years of diligent fire suppression (Federal Reserve 
manipulation since 1940), you build up a lot of underbrush, which is fuel 
(misallocated capital) and you get megaevents like the Yellowstone fires of 
the late 1980's (and The Unfolding Great Collapse - it's a process, not an 
event).  Recessions and depressions are times when the market is cleared of 
misallocations.  The clearing price often is 10% of what was paid at the 
top.  Forest fires are times when the fuel load is removed from the 
forest.  You can't have a healthy ecosystem without them.  For the first 
time in US history, we have two generations of people who have never known 
hard times.  You can't have a healthy human ecosystem in the absence of 
understanding of history.

comments.text:
I listened to an Alaska Native speaker, Larry Merculieff, give a talk 
recently on what Western science can learn from Alaska Native wisdom. It 
was fascinating. One of the things he mentioned that really struck me was 
the relationship of beavers to the health of salmon runs. 

Salmon, said Mr. Merculieff, are starting to pick up parasites that 
normally would not be found in their ranges but are moving northward as the 
ocean warms. At the same time, snowpack melt is faster and more abrupt in 
the spring than it used to be. Instead of gradual melting, rivers are 
flooding violently in the spring and then running lower in the summer. 
Because of this, spawning salmon are more likely to get lesions as they 
traverse the rivers and streams, making them more vulnerable to the 
parasites - and reducing the number of salmon that are able to complete 
their long journeys and reach their spawning grounds.

It seems that biologists were concerned about the salmon runs, and the 
health of the salmon in general. Some of the biologists asked a group of 
Alaska Native elders for their opinions on what might be causing the 
problems for the salmon, and whether they'd seen problems like these in the 
past. Have you noticed, replied the elders, how many more beaver dams there 
are in recent years? 

Well, this immediately confused the scientists. What do beavers have to do 
with salmon? They didn't pay much attention to the elders after that.  

But the beavers? Well, the beaver population has been increasing, and the 
range of beavers has been moving northward. As the number of beavers 
increases, more water is retained on land instead of adding to the flow of 
streams and rivers - compounding the problem of the shallower waterways. 
Observing the beavers gives insight into changes in the ecosystem as a 
whole. It is one piece of a very complex, interwoven tapestry of life in 
the Arctic and sub-Arctic. What seems unrelated rarely if ever *is*. 

This is not the same talk I heard (the one I attended wasn't recorded, 
though I wish it had been), but he is talking about many of the same 
things: TEDxHomer-Larry Merculieff-Native Knowing.
comments.author: Christina Talbott-Clark

top_comment.text:
My father lives in the Bitterroot Valley in Montana. He runs a fly fishing 
and sporting goods store, so he is in constant contact with hunters and 
fishermen from all over Montana and northern Idaho. He also speaks to 
police and game wardens and keeps up on local environmental news, for 
obvious reasons. Here's what he has to tell me:

The elk herd in Yellowstone has collapsed from 18,000 to fewer than 3,000 
animals. There are no moose left in Yellowstone -- none. They're all gone. 
Destroyed. 

The whitetail herds in the Bitterroot have been wiped out. The mule deer 
are staying at higher altitudes and are half-starving. The elk herds are 
collapsing or migrating away. What was the richest sport hunting grounds in 
North America has turned into a desert. Locals are having to drive six 
hours to eastern Montana to fill their deer and elk tags. The number of 
local outfitters has been reduced by two thirds over the past several 
years, with a commensurate effect on the local economy. (Imagine if the 
tourist traffic in San Francisco were reduced by two thirds in a few years. 
What would happen to the local economy? to drug use? to the homeless 
problem)?

The local police department gets reports of wolf sightings every day. A 
young woman out jogging was killed and eaten and her remains dragged so far 
so fast the trackers never recovered her. (Imagine that was your daughter. 
Imagine you have no legal recourse, and if you shoot a wolf menacing one of 
your surviving children you bid fair to be ruined or imprisoned). Armed men 
are standing guard at the school bus stops in the early morning. The 
official figures say there are 5000 wolves in the northwestern US; the 
local DFG biologists are looking at scat and tracks and carcasses and 
saying no, there are at least that many in Montana alone. Those that do not 
toe the politicized party line are transferred or fired.

In response to this catastrophe, the Feds are permitting 300 wolf tags to 
be issued per. year. This will not even make a dent in the growth of the 
wolf population. In the ranching country of northern Idaho there have been 
whole herds of cattle and sheep wiped out -- slaughtered for fun, many run 
to death with no bite marks on them. The governor of Idaho has openly 
declared he will not enforce any Federal laws prohibiting wolf hunting, and 
is wink-nudge encouraging people to shoot them. Politics in Montana is 
somewhat more heavily dominated by migrant greenie-fascist control freaks; 
the kind that launch frivolous lawsuits to prevent the logging of 
fire-killed timber (which subsequently turns into a fire hazard and 
disease/bug factory that, in time, kills yet more of the surrounding 
forest). So the governor's office has not been quite so forthcoming.

The reintroduction of wolves into Yellowstone may be the greatest single 
catastrophe since the near-extermination of the buffalo herds. It took a 
century to push wolves out of that country the last time, and make it safe 
for human civilization. God only knows how long it'll take this time.

And none of it ever makes the news. Who cares about a bunch of stupid 
filthy red-state bipeds anyway...? As long as you suburban 
'environmentalists' can feel good about yourselves, that's all that matters.

/spit﻿

comments.text:
I appreciate your input, but please do not mislead the public like this.  
Many of your statements are completely false.

I'm not sure what capacity your father works with hunters and fishermen in 
the area.  I work for the USFW office in Missoula, and have a strong grasp 
of the ecology in the Bitterroot, Yellowstone, and rural Montana and 
Idaho.  First off, THERE HAVE BEEN NO HUMAN FATALITIES due to wolves in 
Yellowstone in modern history.  That must be a rumor or out-and-out lie. 

MOOSE ARE NOT EXTINCT in the area.  They are seen in the area often by 
tourists and biologists.  Their numbers have taken a small hit from 
carnivores, but they are not primary prey targets, so the impact is 
minimal. 

ELK ARE DOING FINE in the area.  Both of the estimates you give are very 
inaccurate.  When calculating the population for recent hunting permits, it 
was estimated around 18,400.  A healthy population means more hunting 
permits, so the NPS would have no reason to overestimate this number.

PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE DO NOT LOG ON AND SPILL MISINFORMATION LIKE THIS.  IT 
IS NOT HELPING ANYBODY.

comments.text:
So it is cool to call you a bitch? And why Larry's female? Your 
sugardaddy?  Nah, too easy. You know, that is how you call a female dog, 
right? Maybe you wanted to walk into this one. Anyway, not the point. Just 
curious about your choice of words. Being somebody's something validates 
you? Or, you are Larry's female persona. I can't know if I can't see you. 
These are legitimate questions, not a trash talk. No matter, lets talk 
symbolism. You can tell me if you want though. Anyway.
    And since we are talking about symbolism, lets see where yours comes 
from. It is a christian proverb that portrays a non christian, supposedly 
infiltrating the flock under false pretenses. So, wolf is the bad guy here, 
who is trying to break up the hail Jesus business, but trying to be civil 
about it, instead of pointing out how childish it is to follow somebody who 
speaks on behalf of somebody you never met, and will never do. Hence the 
sheep clothing.
     Now, most of the old cultures see a wolf as a free spirit who never 
submits to a rule, but lives and survives in equilibrium with nature. 
Despite all the enemies that are trying to end its existence. It doesn't 
fight back unless you stepped on its toes, or its hungry. Either way, its 
about survival.
    Dog symbolizes a sold out wolf, who has been trained to protect its 
master for scraps, and sells out its freedom and integrity for a wooden box 
in a garden and two plates of food a day. Sounds familiar?
     What is a sheep though? Well, just look around. Sheep, dress the same, 
walk the same, talk the same, and do as they told, which is the same. They 
are in a flock after all. Oh, and hope for the better future. Until of 
course its a slaughter day because the master is hungry. It is too late, 
when the knife is at your throat you know. 
   Disclaimer: this has nothing to do with animals. Any similarities are 
purely coincidental and do not represent the opinions or/and beliefs of the 
ones who want to talk crap and don't want to be sued for it. No animals 
were hurt during the construction of this essay. You know, being sheep and 
all. It is churches trademark after all.
    Sheep are innocent though. They have no strength and no much of a 
critical thinking. Dogs on the other hand, go against their brothers, the 
wolves, to protect their masters, who incidentally are the pigs.
   That is how this symbolism works. And it has nothing to do with real 
animals, and how much you love dogs. I am a dog person too. Besides, its 
not easy to tame a wolf. We all compromise. I can't have a wolf friend, so 
I get a dog servant/friend. After all, it behaves the way I taught it, 
which suits my needs.
     You know, punishing it for something that is of its nature, like 
marking the territory, or use it to attack beings I don't like for some 
reason. It makes me feel superior, I am smarter than the dog and it does 
what I want, or else. Surely that sounds familiar. I don't have a dog, but 
that is the way, isn't it?
   Enjoy being a dog. Its better to be a sheep though, relatively speaking. 
You won't have blood on your fur, at least not somebody else's. And wolves 
will only eat as many as needed. Won't kill you for fun like they would 
kill a dog. Symbolically speaking.
   Whether you are winding me up or not, it matters a little. What matters 
is that I am correct. Using your strongest argument. 
  Don't feel bad. Religion is a virus that rewrites itself and deletes 
every other data, some say. Most of the times you don't even know that it 
is kicking in. There is no logic there. Just words of free thought slander. 
   I hope it helped you understand what I meant. Slavery is bad, you know, 
doesn't matter how you sugarcoat it, it is still bad.
   I don't mind talking, I do mind talking to myself though. So if you want 
to hear, I'll gladly tell. As I did, I think.

top_comment.text:
*Complex interrelationships between Earth and life.* Changing levels of a 
single species can have far-reaching impacts on local plants and animals - 
and even change the course of rivers. 

*"When we try to pick out anything by itself, we find it hitched to 
everything else in the Universe."* John Muir

We have discovered that food chains are also webs - and that complex 
interrelationships can have far-reaching impacts that are difficult to 
predict.

The human-led near-extermination of the wolves changed Yellowstone. The 
human-led attempt to undo the damage changed it, too.  But additional 
studies show that not all that was lost has been restored:

● Stream hydrology limits recovery of riparian ecosystems after wolf 
reintroduction. (
http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/280/1756/20122977)

● Are wolves saving Yellowstone's aspen? A landscape-level test of a 
behaviorally mediated trophic cascade. (
http://www.wyocoopunit.org/index.php/archives/2010/kauffman-m-j-j-brodie-and-e-s-jules-2010-are-wolves-saving-yello/
)

We know that the activities of humans and other species can create 
fascinating and long-term changes in our environment. Predicting those 
changes - and how those changes may affect us - remains a difficult and 
important challenge.

An international team of scientists published a study on the loss of 
animals in the Anthropocene, the Earth's current geologic time period, 
 where the rise of humans and human activities have begun a significant 
impact on the Earth's ecosystems. 

*[H]uman impacts on animal biodiversity are an under-recognized form of 
global environmental change. Among terrestrial vertebrates, 322 species 
have become extinct since 1500, and populations of the remaining species 
show 25% average decline in abundance. Invertebrate patterns are equally 
dire: 67% of monitored populations show 45% mean abundance decline. Such 
animal declines will cascade onto ecosystem functioning and human 
well-being.*

http://www.sciencemag.org/content/345/6195/401

http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/07/140724171956.htm

"Two billion years ago, cyanobacteria oxygenated the atmosphere and 
powerfully disrupted life on earth,” [Andrew Revkin] says. “But they didn’t 
know it. We’re the first species that’s become a planet-scale influence and 
is aware of that reality. That’s what distinguishes us.”

http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/what-is-the-anthropocene-and-are-we-in-it-164801414/#u4Rc8ff87u3KmGAL.99

1-Aug-2014: Edited to credit the international research team - h/t +Rich 
Pollett. 

  #interconnected   #ecology   #earthscience   #lifescience﻿

comments.author: mewmew34

comments.text:
+BigRalphSmith "Humans are responsible for the decision. The size of the 
population making it actually makes no difference."
- While this might be true in the sense that the ones responsible are human 
I fail to see how that means that humanity or all humans are responsible. 
Surely you wouldn't say that if I committed a crime that you should be 
blamed for it, no less all of humanity?

"Intelligence allows a species to alter the environment and the 
availability of resources rather than adjusting to it. In some cases, this 
has no detrimental effect. In others, it quite obviously does."
"This is a case of simple probability."
- So if I understood you correctly you are saying something like this:
1. A intelligent species can alter the environment (rather than adjust to 
it).
2. Altering the environment can have either detrimental effect (toward the 
ecosystem) or lack such effect.
3. As a "case of simple probability" a intelligent species will inevitably 
alter the environment in ways that have detrimental effect.
Conclusion: Intelligent species are detrimental to a ecosystem.

I take issue with step 2 since it seems plausible to me that one could 
alter the environment in ways which benefits the biosphere. As long as that 
the case I would be of the opinion that your position is based upon a false 
dichotomy. Furthermore if altering the environment can have beneficial 
effects then if we just see it as a case of simple probability it would 
seem that intelligence neither is detrimental or beneficial to a biosphere. 
Now I would think it natural to infer that a intelligent species would tend 
to act in a way which benefited the ecosystem it lives in. If my line of 
thought is correct it would lead to an conclusion which is opposite to 
yours.

It may be the case that I'm wrong though, in which case you would simply 
need to either show your conclusion isn't based on a false dichotomy but a 
true one or you could make the case that intelligent species tend toward 
acting in ways detrimental toward the ecosystem it lives in.
comments.author: Paradoxarn

comments.text:
+Paradoxarn
Humans are responsible for the decision. The size of the population making 
it actually makes no difference.

Intelligence allows for behavior that is detrimental to ecological 
stability. I'm surprised I need to point that out. All other species 
naturally tend toward ecological balance because their actions are dictated 
by their environment and naturally available resources.
Intelligence allows a species to alter the environment and the availability 
of resources rather than adjusting to it. In some cases, this has no 
detrimental effect. In others, it quite obviously does. Case in point, the 
aforementioned artificial control of the wolf population.

This is a case of simple probability. It almost seems to me like you are 
taking the actions of of a population "personally" simply because you 
happen to belong to that population. Nothing could be further from the 
truth. It's a function of intelligence, not malice. Remember, this is a 
cascade effect. Cascades are difficult to predict so of course humans are 
going to make mistakes when endeavoring to alter the balance of fauna but 
that fact does not absolve us of responsibility for the mistake itself.

I agree that it is a good thing that we have learned from that mistake and 
are taking steps to correct it.
comments.author: BigRalphSmith

comments.text:

Couldn't agree more.
comments.author: Paradoxarn

comments.text:
+Paradoxarn
Well, yes, humanity should be blamed for all the bad decisions made 
collectively. As they are responsible for those decisions, who else would 
you blame? That's not to say that we made such decisions with bad 
intentions but blame is not assigned by intent (or lack of intent), it is 
assigned by responsibility.
I agree that correcting our mistakes is a good thing but it doesn't matter 
why we made those mistakes, we made them so yes, we are to blame.
I'd say it is a fact that the ecosystem would be better off if there were 
no intelligent species living on the planet but that observation doesn't 
mean I think the human race should die tomorrow.

top_comment.text:
This video isn't telling the correct story about the wolves.  Deer and Elk 
wouldn't be hard on the river banks.  Buffalo like cattle might.  This 
video would lead you to believe that adding the non native invasive species 
(timer wolf) to the ecosystem has been all sugar plumbs and fairies.  The 
elk and deer and moose populations in the park has declined not risen.  The 
deer, elk and moose have been decimated outside of the park.  Point in case 
would be the Bitteroot national forest.  Before the wolves 16000 elk and 
good moose populations.  Now 1000 elk and almost no moose.  The Montana 
wildlife service is so desperate to control the wolves they now have to 
dramatically decrease the wolf numbers by using helicopters to hunt them. 
 The revenue in the states that have wolves has cost hundreds of millions 
of dollars.  all for a non native invasive species.  The grey wolf would be 
the native wolf.  a totally different wolf an about half the size.  the 
timber wolf is from Canada.﻿

comments.text:
I was talking about wolves in Yellowstone, not Bitterroot. I know nothing 
about Bitterroot national forest. If they did introduce timber wolves there 
then that was a dumb move. Ecosystems aren't adapted for invasive species. 
But the wolves in Yellowstone were grey wolves. Which is what this video 
was talking about in the first place. It would make sense that introducing 
an invasive species such as the timber wolf would cause elk populations to 
drop so drastically. But its not because they just added wolves, its 
because they added the wrong wolf. I am fairly certain that if they had 
reintroduced the proper species then the ecosystem would have 
re-stabilized, not cause such drastic population decline.
comments.author: Brooke R

numbers they didn't crash like that. The gray wolf was not what was 
introduced it's the timber wolf you are wrong. The native grey wasn't an

wolves aren't there to stunt that...not mention the shiras moose which may

comments.author: Trent Haverfield

comments.text:
+Trent Haverfield The wolves that were reintroduced into Yellowstone were 
the native grey wolves. And the elk population in Yellowstone is from about 
10000-20000 in the summer. Also populations of animals in an ecosystem ebb 
and flow. As numbers of wolves increase and numbers of elk decrease the 
wolves will find that there is less food. As a result they will begin to 
starve and die off, decreasing the population. This allows for the elk 
population to increase because there will be less predators. The ecosystem 
can control its own population, there is no need for human intervention.

top_comment.text:
This is the best short video I have ever seen on how important facts that 
we as humans don't understand yet can help us improve our natural 
environments. Thanks to +Petra Muchova for her sharing this on her pages 
and starting me thinking about this.  The wonder of it is that this 
occurred after gradual reintroduction of wolves.  I know quite a few of us 
understand the ideas around keystone species and what happens to wild 
populations when they grow beyond resource capability to sustain them, but 
this concept too needs to be done clearly in a short video like this.  This 
4+ minute video is so well narrated and the video is incredibly well 
edited, brief, and catches my attention and holds it.  No wonder you are 
getting up to 3 million views.  Hurray.   This is how our scientists need 
to begin getting their important work out.  Avoid the jargon.  Tell 
interesting stories.  Alan Alda is working with the State University of New 
York at Stony Brook to do the same type of thing by helping scientists and 
engineers speak more effectively to ordinary people like me who don't speak 
the jargon of science.  Your organization should cooperate with him.  
Here's the link below.  It's from Alda's keynote speech at the American 
Association for the Advancement of Science Meeting in Chicago just a few 
weeks ago.
   
http://www.centerforcommunicatingscience.org/advocating-and-teaching-science-communication/

#wolves     #ecosystemhealth   #keystonespecies     #ecosystemcollapse   
#yellowstonenationalpark   ﻿
top_comment.author: Frank Elliott

comments.text: +Graeme McRae good find, gives way more detail
comments.author: Screwy Wabbit

comments.text:
+Graeme McRae
What a wonderful article.   Thank you Graeme.    I think what this article 
introduces very well is the idea of complexity.   An ecosystem involves 
multiple streams of interrelated independent variables and streams of 
causation.   When I see that the cause is just one variable like wolf 
reintroduction impacting elks and then causing them to graze less or in 
less volume, then I get very concerned.   What I've learned through my 
experiences with survey research is that there are usually at least a few 
very important variables.  It makes sense to me that an absolute control 
like fences around the Aspen will make those trees grow much higher 
generally.  The Elk can't reach them anymore.  Wolves on the other hand 
will control  the eating of those saplings partially and intermittently.    
There are many times when the wolves will just not be around and others 
when they are full and not interested.  If there's a very dry season, the 
Aspen will be stunted as a very cold growing period will do.   Beavers are 
another important species.   I think that great article says they are good 
for forests too.    So, there is both top down and bottom up control and 
many scientists think we really need to look at the middle level.   I enjoy 
this kind of reading very much and what it brings to mind is that it is 
really important here to have an ethnological study of the forest and 
biosphere in the park where citizen scientists observe careful, measure and 
record, and gather many, many data points.  It's like  some of the famous 
studies that have been done of native peoples and their culture like the 
famed anthropologist Margaret Mead did.  Here's a good link to her work 
from a wonderful Library of Congress Exhibition:
http://www.loc.gov/exhibits/mead/field-samoa.html
    In this case, we have the computing power and perhaps a large group of 
citizen scientists who could really help us understand that Yellowstone 
ecosystem.  Citizen science as a way to augment the capabilities and data 
gathering power of scientists is becoming more and more important.  
   Here's a blog about citizen science which I enjoy very much.  There is a 
great deal of good information on recommended computer science projects, 
nature projects, and many new happenings in the science world where 
volunteers work with scientists to make science possible.
http://www.openscientist.org/2014/02/big-news-from-openscientist.html?showComment=1394506391130#c8376365515129550555 
 
I used to do quite a bit of this kind of thing by participating in a 
medicine discovery computing project on BOINC the University of 
California's backbone internet system for many citizen science projects for 
distributed computing for science.
comments.author: Frank Elliott

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Clive Williams It's made me think back to the series Connection(s) by 
James Burke a few decades ago.  I think of all the nature and 
conservation/ecology research that went into understanding this.  How many 
streams of knowledge and wisdom are coming together? I am reminded again 
and again to walk humbly in my so called certainties and to realize that 
some of my knowledge is very rudimentary.  It is so important to learn to 
listen well and hear the truths and stories of others and what their truths 
are.  I am beginning to understand pretty deeply why some of the very best 
scientists and truth seekers I have known were so very humble and really 
knew how to frame good questions.  I'm looking forward to Sunday evening 
and the new Cosmos series to begin on Fox and National Geographic 
Channels.   I think Neil DeGrasse Tyson is a very bright human being.  I 
hope he can pull the renewal of that famed Carl Sagan series off just as 
well as Sagan did.    I know many millions of us are just counting the 
hours down to 9 pm on Sunday Night. I think that's when it is in 
Minneapolis (Central Time).   And, yes.   It is amazing and to think of all 
the cases where we don't understand the cascade of causality.  It will come 
though if we learn to be more patient and thoughtful.
comments.author: Frank Elliott

comments.text:
+frogsoda I think the point was to show just how essential the wolves were 
to the maintenance of the eco-system.  The deer leave certain areas where 
they are more easily hunted by wolves, namely flat, open terrain.  So yes, 
the wolves follow the deer, but they are less successful in the areas where 
they now reside.  

and the wolf population isn't likely to explode.  I hope at some point you 
were taught the basic environmental mechanism of predator/prey cycles.  the 
two populations kept each other in check for a long time before humans, and 
they'll do the same thing now.  

The idea that hunters can act as a replacement for wolves is 
over-simplifying the relationship.  Hunters operate in a different way and 
on a different scale.  For one thing, human hunters tend to favor large, 
strong prey, and particularly males, as hunting trophies, therefore 
actually selecting AGAINST the healthiest individuals of the population, 
while wolves target the young, old, weak, and sick.  Humans don't hunt 
territorially, so deer are picked off at random rather than establishing 
specific areas.  And finally, humans don't live as an integrated part of 
the eco-system, and so aren't as responsive to it as a species that is a 
natural inhabitant.  The area has taken thousands of years to develop the 
mechanisms on which it now operates, and an incomplete human understanding 
of it makes them imperfect replacements for a keystone species.

+Alex Blank OK, First. I hope you meant "ravenous" instead of "rabid".
Second, You would be amazed at what a couple of gunshots will do to clear 
an area of deer. (elk, actually)
Third. I know what the point is. The point is that Americans are programmed 
to believe whatever they are told to believe, especially if it's by a guy 
with a British accent. Thank you, David Attenborough.
But if you DID actually think about it, you might ask yourself, If the 
deer(elk) were leaving certain areas because of wolves, did the wolves just 
stay there and wonder where all the deer(elk) went? Or did they go where 
there was venison? Also, Bears like a bit of venison every now and then 
too. And Bears don't *have* to depend on wolves for a meal. Bears and 
wolves aren't exactly playmates.

I'm not saying that wolves had no effect on this environment. Of course 
they did, they are apex predators. But what I am saying is that maybe there 
were other factors unrelated to the wolves.
But since "the point" is to show what a difference one species can make, we 
may never know what those other factors were. And we can't predict what 
will happen when the wolves become overpopulated and the deer(elk) 
population dwindles.  
99% of all species that have lived on this planet are extinct. The vast 
majority before humans ever stood on two legs. And yet the planet has done 
quite well.

top_comment.text:
"Conflict management starts with self management."   And how does 
self-management affect others?   The short video "How Wolves Change Rivers" 
is a wonderful example of how small changes affecting one species changed 
an entire ecosystem.   When the wolves came back, although few in number, 
the deer started avoiding certain places.  As a result, trees and grasses 
that had been over-grazed multiplied.   Rare animals like weasels and 
beavers began to thrive.  And eventually the river stabilized and flowed 
differently.   If you need a shot of hope that change is possible, and 
small steps can make a difference, take a break for four minutes and view 
this!   ﻿

comments.text:
+Tessa Schlesinger On something as enormous as climate change, I entirely 
agree. And yet...there *must* be wise ways we can geo-engineer solutions 
along the same lines as re-introducing wolves into Yellowstone. 

An example is a UK project that exemplifies what I think of as "wise" 
engineering: The Medmerry Coastal Realignment Project. To reduce flooding 
from storm surges, rather than make the seawall higher (traditional 
engineering), they decided to bust a hole in the seawall and create a new 
wetlands area. It absorbs storm surges and reduces the risk of flooding for 
a huge surrounding area.

Source: http://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-24770379

The domino effect from this tiny change will likely be large, and, 
hopefully, positive, because it works with natural forces in a wise way, 
rather than working against them.

But on a macro scale like climate change, you are entirely right. We humans 
can often engineer (think) our way out of micro problems. But macro, 
systemic, structural problems? We simply don't possess that level of wisdom 
and enlightenment.
comments.author: Jeff Posey

comments.text:
+Beatriz Palacios I remember that article, they also found out that's why 
trees produce latex, it's a nasty-tasting and smelling polymer that repels 
foragers from damaging their bodies. They need these mechanisms to defend 
themselves because their cellulose cell walls are so rigid that they cannot 
make fast movements like an animal.

Some plants are so soft yet rigid that they can move, the mimosa, for 
example. It will curl up like it's been tickled, and there are others that 
move constantly even to the naked eye.

What makes some people think these creatures aren't alive because they 
don't have the same blood as us or run away in fear of being killed?

Not only do some fish in the arctic have blue to silver-colored blood, not 
red, but plants actually have a circulatory system, they eat, drink, 
breathe, and grow by cellular division. That in my book constitutes as a 
life, and those experiments have made my suspicions into a reality: they 
are conscious life-forms. They don't need to move for me to love them, I 
have plants all over the place and I love them all. I also love my animals!
comments.author: Lycantis

+Beatriz Palacios Me, too, and I have no guilt or regrets eating animals. I 
am perfectly aware a life was taken to sustain several people with food, 
but what does sicken me is the industrial meat companies that make highly

an animal that will be eaten.

About the trees, they did many experiments, and one thing they found was a 
stress hormone from grass that was being cut literally calling out for 
help. The response was ants coming and attacking the assaulter, which in 
the wild would be an animal, who would move away from the grass there and 
chew on a different patch to get away from the ants. The ants proceeded to 
clean the wounds on the grass and keep it safe until it could scab over and 
recover, it was pretty amazing.

comments.text:
+Beatriz Palacios Agreed, we should be eating everything, and saturated fat 
is actually more beneficial than seed and vegetable oils, which are high in 
Omega 6 and can cause gastrointestinal distress that leads to other 
problems.

However, vegetarians are in the clear as they get their B12 from cheeses, 
occasional chicken and fish (why they avoid red meat altogether is beyond 
me), and eggs, which are high in B12. Vegans cannot. They avoid all animal 
protein and thus they are unhealthy. There is no plant source of vitamin 
B12 on this planet, only herbivores make it with help from the special gut 
flora that has to be in an alkali environment. Omnivores and carnivores are 
too acidic to support it and nothing can change that. Our physiology does 
not support veganism, and it actually reacts poorly to vegetarianism, but 
at least the latter gets some of the essential mineral.

I believe in harmony, and how can we, as a species, be harmonious at all if 
we do not take from the lessons of our fellow Earth creatures. To think 
killing for sustenance is evil, implies that innocent animals are evil. And 
another thing, last time I checked plants were alive, when did this change? 
I laugh when people throw the "morality" in my face because how moral is it 
to reject the flesh of one organism because it moves and makes noise, but 
then devour the flesh of another organism that is defenseless and cannot 
make noise audible to human ears? Recordings have proven trees scream in 
pain when their limbs are being cut off, but humans cannot hear it. Makes 
you wonder.

I love all life, not just animals, plants are alive, too.
comments.author: Lycantis

Уникальное открытие: Волки помогают расти деревьям, течь рекам и процветать 
бесчисленным видам.

Это может показаться не очевидным на первый взгляд, но волки могут иметь 
огромное косвенное воздействие на экосистемы. Они не только влияют на 
сокращение численности популяции оленей и других травоядных; они в корне 
меняют их поведение, их места для пастбищ и места, которые они избегают. 
Это означает, что деревья и растения начинают снова расти в тех местах, где 
были пастбища, давая приют для всех видов животных (певчих птиц, бобров, 
кроликов). 

Это создает круговорот работы местных экосистем, предоставляя больше 
экологических ниш для большого количества видов, пока через несколько лет 
область не оживет до неузнаваемости! Все это благодаря волкам, этого 
недооцененного хищника вершин!

Помните: Речь идет не просто о волках. Хищники везде находятся под угрозой 
и это вызовет негативные последствия во всех экосистемах…

Посмотрите отличное видео ниже, чтобы увидеть цепь событий в действии, как 
волки вновь изменили Йеллоустоун после 70-летнего отсутствия...

comments.text:
+Stephen Hamilton What I meant is that small changes can have profound 
effects that spread beyond the obvious first level, beyond the non-obvious 
second level, but can have effects many levels beyond that are unforeseen. 

In a business sense, this doesn't mean we benefit from the 'business 
wolves' :) but more that if we make a small change to an internal process, 
or a small change to some other part how we interact with our clients, 
suppliers and staff - that can have an effect beyond what we realise. 

To me, this is incentive to make the tweaks, to test changes, to 'dampen' 
them if they seem to introduce negative ripples, to amplify them if they 
have positive ripples. 

In fact, one should have in mind exactly how you plan to 'dampen' or 
'amplify' a change before you make the change so that you can actively 
engage with the changes and react to them in a considered manner rather 
than an unplanned, unconsidered reactive mode.

comments.text:
+wolf2600 I checked the Wikipedia article on coyote and wolf.
The coyote diet :
“Sometimes labelled as carnivores but more often as omnivores, coyotes are 
opportunistic, versatile feeders. They eat small mammals such as (depending 
on the region in which it lives) voles, prairie dogs, eastern cottontails, 
ground squirrels, mice, birds, snakes, lizards, deer, javelina, and 
livestock, as well as insects and other invertebrates. The coyote will also 
target any species of bird that nests on the ground.”
The wolf diet :
“The gray wolf generally specializes in vulnerable individuals of large 
prey. In Eurasia, many wolf populations are forced to subsist largely on 
livestock and garbage in areas with dense human activity, though wild 
ungulates such as moose, red deer, roe deer and wild boar are still the 
most important food sources in Russia and the more mountainous regions of 
Eastern Europe. Other prey species include reindeer, argali, mouflon, 
wisent, saiga, ibex, chamois, wild goats, fallow deer and musk deer. […] 
Animals preferred as prey by North American wolves include moose, 
white-tailed deer, elk, mule deer, bighorn sheep, Dall's sheep, American 
bison, muskox and caribou.”
Do you see not some difference of scale between the preys of coyotes and 
the preys of wolves ?

And yet still, even though coyotes usually prey on animals much much 
smaller than men, wikipedia mentions that :
“Yet, confirmed reports of coyotes killing a human have been documented.”
And here is their source :
http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/coyotes-kill-toronto-singer-in-cape-breton-1.779304

So, coyotes whose normal preys are way smaller and weaker than humans still 
sometime do kill humans, sure wolves that hunt much bigger preys than 
coyotes would definitely never ever kill humans, lol.

Anyway, you seem to be totally missing the point. Which is “Seems like we 
humans did much worse than what the deers did. Maybe we should purposefully 
get ourselves killed by predators for more awesome biodiversity ?”. Not 
“Hey, let us kill all the wolves because we are afraid they will kill us”.

top_comment.text:
And now I want to share with you one of the most interesting short videos 
I've seen in a while. It's about the idea of *trophic cascades:* how a 
small change to an ecosystem can lead to tremendous consequences. In this 
case, the change was the reintroduction of wolves to Yellowstone in the 
1990's, after a 70-year absence.

The direct effects of the wolves were small: the wolves eat a few deer, but 
apart from that mostly keep to themselves. But the indirect effects were 
huge.

It started because the deer, who had been running roughshod over the entire 
park, quickly figured out that places like valleys were *not good places* 
to be a deer when there are wolves about. This led to trees being able to 
grow in those areas for the first time in decades.

The effects of that are complex and profound, and I encourage you to watch 
the video, because I can't possibly summarize it better than it does. 
Everything from the animals to the plants to the very physical geography of 
the rivers was changed. 

The key lesson of this is that ecosystems are connected. You can't make a 
single change to one and expect it not to have consequences, including very 
far-reaching ones of a sort you couldn't ever have predicted. This is a 
general property of all large, strongly-interacting systems, including 
societies, and it's worth keeping in mind whenever things change.﻿

When wolves were reintroduced to Yellowstone National Park in the United 
States after being absent nearly 70 years, the most remarkable "trophic 
cascade" occurred. What is a trophic cascade and how exactly do wolves 
change rivers? George Monbiot explains in this movie remix.

comments.text:
Sounds like a chain reaction having to deal with the animals and their 
habitats... Basically thanks to the wolves controlling how the deer act by 
continually hunting them, vegetation in the areas that the deer frequent 
less start to rebound. What is important is that the rebound also occurs at 
the banks of the rivers in Yellow Stone, meaning that the roots of the 
plants there hold the ground together thus slowing the erosions of the 
banks themselves. Less or slower erosion means that the rivers cannot 
meander as it has for the past 70 years or so that the wolves were gone.

comments.text:
+Richard Moss
Definetly it is sad when the individual moments happens, but in the long 
run it works. For example, The wolf eats baby deer. The baby deers remains 
stay there. Then scavengers eat remains. Then what's left decomposes and 
forms nutrients for the soil. because of that, new plants grow. The deer 
eat the plants, the deer have babies, and the cycle repeats itself. So it's 
good in the long run.

Is there a different way to express yourself?  I didn't know people often

comments.text:
Until a few months ago I used spell check and auto correct until I realized 
it degraded my normal abilities. 
I think we are pretty close with how we view the natural world. I did give 
the impression that I saw animals on our level of cobsciousness, of course 
thats not the case. Our vocabulary deciphers our thoughts into words, and 
without a deep vocabulary animal thoughts are hard to understand. Oh and 
interestingly enough, animals that live near urban environments gain a 
substantial intelligence boost. They are more intelligent than woodland 
dwellers of the same species. And that agrees wirh your view on third world 
humans compared to first world. Of course we also create people like the 
obese lady. 

Animal cognition is an interesting subject. The current research has 
uncovered many false theories of the past. The current research with 
insects has shown a high level of awareness and understanding of their 
surroundings as well as individual personality driven minds. And I am still 
blown away by what botanists have discovered with plant consciousness.

I may overstate too much or with more emphasis than necessary because I am 
very excited most of the day. Sometimes I notice how crazy my persona is 
compared to others. Positive thoughts are powerful, but over indulging on 
nothing but positive can develope into a loud and overbearing personality.
comments.author: Darren Pellichino

comments.text:
+Darren Pellichino I don't use auto-correct, it doesn't speak English or 
have proper grammar skills. Plus it can make an innocent conversation into 
something very nasty and awkward.

I didn't say humans didn't have emotions based on chemical reactions to 
stimuli, but most 1st world humans have a noted difference in their ability 
to translate it to a 'normal' reaction that every other species, including 
wild humans, have to the stimuli. It's all to do with domestication and the 
dependence on technology. Tech can be a good thing to learn with or create 
with, but it can also be the downfall of some people like that obese woman 
watching American Idol shrieking that her life is over because her favorite 
contestant got booted.

Humans are not the only animals to hunt for sport, though, but other 
animals at least eat the food they play with instead of wasting it. I saw 
that in a conversation up there and can't remember who it was between but 
people are of the opinion that 1) humans are the only species that has fun 
while hunting or hunts for sport, and that 2) herbivores are vegans. 
Neither is truth. All animals eat other animals, as well as plants, which 
are also living creatures, it is the nature of the world. Humans just tend 
to screw up when it comes to playing their part on the planet.

comments.text:
+Darren Pellichino Yes, we do still retain traits that are shared with 
animals, that will never go away, but human emotion is a far cry from 
animal. Animals do indeed have emotion, theirs is very different than that 
of the modern, spoiled people, however. Better to look at humans who live 
in the wild to see natural human behavior. They are too busy surviving to 
act like idiots over stupid things like hot celebrities and such who hoard 
money while people around them starve. Those wild people help feed each 
other, instead. Much like other primate species.

It's more a matter of domestication, the more domesticated a dog is, the 
worse off it is in the wild, but it maintains its innocence in thought, it 
can also learn to cope and survive if lost in the wild. The more domestic a 
human is, the more privileged and greedy they become and they lose all 
ability to survive without being pampered to smithereens. There will always 
be exceptions to these examples, as everything is unique in both physical 
and mental behavior and appearance.

Second, because secondly is incorrect, is that they do not backstab. They 
fight for dominance and territory. You would never see an animal hurt its 
own community members to slow an enemy down. Nor a member turning on one or 
more for some sort of monetary or like gain. You will only see fighting for 
alpha status, which is not the same thing. Your example was not a backstab. 
There was no friendship or social connection between the two species, they 
just didn't feel like fighting the bear and the bear knew exactly what they 
were doing. You put someone chasing all of those animals, they will all 
run, the bear won't attack the wolves to make the enemy focus on them 
instead, that would be a backstab of sorts. But even then it does not count 
as they are completely different species who have different languages and 
social behaviors.

There really is no twist, you cannot compare animal behavior to modern 
societal behavior because 1st world humans are so far from nature they 
aren't even a part of it. 3rd world generally have a more survivalist 
behavior system, with the absolute wild humans behaving the most like other 
primate species but utilizing tools and weapons that separates them from 
mere animals.

And last, it's *you're. You are saying I own a looking, as in it's "your 
looking" or in essence "my looking".
comments.author: Lycantis

comments.text:
+Lycantis I see what your looking at as examples of the behavior. But I 
also see the situation is somehow twisting its logic when you try to make 
sense of it.

Examples....We are still fighting over territory and mating rights. The 
green pieces of paper are the same. You can buy land and mates with it. 
When a deer takes a harem he has more wealth. Its the same thing caused by 
the same drive.

Secondly animals are 100% equipped to backstab. They are constantly waging 
a war of deception onto one another. When a turtle flicks his tongue so 
fish will come to eat, that is his stab to the back. Elaborate 
communication is needed to become friends on our level.

Best example....Grizzly bear decides to hang with wolf pack when they go 
out for hunt. Wolves are not threatened so they go on their hunt like 
normal while bear is right amongst them, like another wolf. Once they kill 
caribou grizzly attacks them and plants himself on kill. He fights them off 
for several minutes until wolves go away. That was a backstab. Imagine what 
we don't see.
comments.author: Darren Pellichino

comments.text:
+Darren Pellichino We're doing worse than animals, I am not bashing, it's 
the truth. Animals fight over territory and food, humans fight over a 
monetary system and pieces of paper that have no definitive wealth. Also, 
animals would never backstab each other, that's a human thing. Humans 
really are greedy whether you choose to believe it or not. I didn't say all

in the long run the reason we are separated is because of our nature. We 
are not like other animals, the fact that you cling to that lie shows that 
you are blissfully ignorant.

Love that you clumped all humans together and said that's what I said, when 
I clearly did not. You are putting words in my mouth. I am one of the 
animal lovers and nature lovers that strives to better the planet by 
educating people about the impact humans have on the environment. At least 
some people got a clue and decided to undo the damage humans caused by 
wiping out the wolves, and put the wolves back into their native habitat. 
But people are complaining about it because "scary wolves!" ...Yeah there 
were scary bears there but you seem fixated on the wolves. Those wolves are 
what's keeping the land looking alive, it was turning into a wasteland

is declining so rapidly the government's in a panic. They didn't bother 
listening to the environmental experts that told them not to remove them 
ever. Wolves should always be protected.

+Darren Pellichino Difference between selfishness and survival. Killing off

Yes, we are animals, but humans go so far off track from their roots when

comments.text:
+Jeff Freeman You know, I don't know everything so I might have overstated 
that there are no animals that have " fun" in killing. I have been reading 
somewhere that there are actually some species of monkeys that are known to 
have " wars"  with weapons and all. However in highly most of the cases 
there will be a logical explanation for a behavior we perceive as being " 
killing for sport" . 

However that a wolf, or even a pack, would kill for sport has been a long 
standing myth that fed on people's (imho irrational) fear or even disgust 
for this animal. What I put above is not something I assume, it is 
something that is the conclusion of people who have followed and documented 
the wolves, that have studied his behavior for many years. Are there 
animals that kill for other reasons than food and defence or territory, 
perhaps. Are wolves one of those species? I have presented my reasons why 
to say no.

I can understand the dislike farmers for example have for wolves, or any 
predatory animal for that matter but as far as I am concerned we (humanity) 
live by the grace of the world around us and not the other way around

top_comment.text:
This short video came to my attention again recently and after watching it 
again the impact is just the same. It really is quite amazing how the 
reintroduction of a top predator such as the wolves of Yellowstone National 
Park has had such a profound effect on the eco systems of the park. After 
an absence of 70 years their reintroduction in 1995 has helped the park to 
regenerate..
The grasslands of the valleys and the gorges started to regenerate, trees 
grew taller, forests returned and the number of birds increased. Beaver 
numbers started to increase which provided habitats for other animals such 
as ducks, otters, fish, frogs and other reptiles. 
It’s a great story which culminates in changing the physical geography of 
the park and demonstrates how everything is interconnected.﻿
top_comment.author: Ian Macleod

comments.text:
+David R Robinson "know the wolves are still very controversial"  Just some 
things to think about.  Golden retrievers have killed more people in the 
past 50 years then the entire recorded history of US wolf caused deaths.  
Aside from them being superior in strength cunning and killer instinct- 
they are also highly intelligent and observant of their surroundings.  They 
can hold grudges against other wolves- do you not think when they see their 
family members caught in traps, poisoned or shot by us this might build 
some resentment towards our type?  They are also excellent at judging body 
language, over three times better at reading human body- then humans do 
without training, picking up subtle micro ticks and slight posture changes 
invisible to most.  They understand provocation and threatening postures 
innately and many attacks can be linked to provocation even if 
unintentional.   What is our excuse for massacring their population across 
the country- its so ranchers can cut corners and sadists can kill a highly 
evolved creature.

comments.text:
+Wazzy Shaik
Animals evolve to fit pretty specific niches.  Wolves eat different animals 
than lions or tigers would.  Just the same as they are different from the 
already native foxes, coyotes, bears, and others.  The lions or tigers 
would not target the same animals.  They would behave differently.  They 
would have a completely different effect.  That is why it is always 
important to prevent extinction or local extirpation of certain species, 
because once they are gone they can not truly be replaced.

captions.text:
One of the most exciting scientific findings
of the past half century has been the discovery
of widespread trophic cascades.

A trophic cascade is an ecological process
which starts at the top of the food chain
and tumbles all the way down to the bottom.

And the classic example is what happened in
the Yellowstone National Park

in the United States when wolves were reintroduced
in 1995.

Now, we all know that wolves kill various
species of animals, but perhaps we're slightly
less aware
that they give life to many others.

Before the wolves turned up - they'd been
absent for 70 years -

the numbers of deer (because there had been
nothing to hunt them) had built up and built
up in the Yellowstone Park
and despite efforts by humans to control them

they'd managed to reduce much the vegitation
there to almost nothing. They had just grazed
it away.

But as soon as the wolves arrived, even though
they were few in number
they started to have the most remarkable effects.

First, of course, they killed some of the
deer but that wasn't the major thing.

Much more significantly, they radically changed
the behavior of the deer.

The deer started avoiding certain parts of
the park - the places where they could be
trapped most easily -
particularly the valleys and the gorges
and immediately those places started to regenerate.

In some areas, the height of the trees quintupled
in just six years.

Bare valley sides quickly became forests of
aspen and willow and cottonwood.

And as soon as that happened, the birds started
moving in.

The number of songbirds and migratory birds
started to increase greatly.

The number of beavers started to increase
because beavers like to eat the trees.
And beavers, like wolves, are ecosystem engineers.
They create niches for other species.

And the dams they built in the rivers provided
habitats for otters and muscrats and ducks
and fish and reptiles and amphibians.

The wolves killed coyotes and as a result
of that, the number rabbits and mice began
to rise
which meant more hawks
more weasels
more foxes
more badgers

Ravens and bald eagles came down to feed on
the carrion that the wolves had left.

Bears fed on it, too. And their population
began to rise as well

partly also because there were more berries
growing on the regenerating shrubs.

And the bears reinforced the impact of the
wolves by killing some of the calves of the
deer.
But here's where it gets really interesting.
The wolves changed the behavior of the rivers.

They began to meander less. There was less
erosion.

The channels narrowed. More pools formed.
More riffle sections.
All of which were great for wildlife habitats.
The rivers changed in response to the wolves.

And the reason was that the regenerating forests
stabilized the banks so that they collapsed
less often.
So the rivers became more fixed in their course.

Similarly, by driving the deer out of some
places,

and the vegetation recovering on the valley
side,

there was less soil erosion because the vegitation
stabilized that as well.

So the wolves, small in number, transformed
not just the ecosystem of the Yellowstone
National Park

-This huge area of land... but also, its physical
geography.
